Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6420, file 863-5, part 1)
Ottawa,
February 15, 1944.

Mr. S. Mallinson, Indian Agent, Hazelton, B.C.

The Department finds it necessary to return your voucher No. 303 issued in favour of the Hudson's Bay Company. If you review this account you will find that the correct total is $11.50, not $14.20. We have made corrections in other Hudson's Bay Company accounts previously and when we sent a smaller cheque than the amount requested the company invariably returned the cheque and asked for an explanation. As a result there has always been considerable unnecessary correspondence. It is, therefore, felt that it would be advisable to return this account and have the company correct it before payment is made.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Your file 151-21-4

With reference to Mr. Phelan's letter of December 7, 1943 authorizing the purchase of supplies for the Kitwancool Indian Day School, I wish to advise that it was necessary to purchase an Airtight heater for this school. I am taking the liberty of including the price of this heater under the above mentioned authority and trust that my action will have your approval.

I may say the six gallons of floor oil is not procurable at the present time and that the elbow and reducer are not now required. I have therefore deleted these articles from your authority.

S. Mallinson
Indian Agent
Babine Agency

Hazelton, B.C.
February 4th., 1944

Indian Commissioner for B.C., P.O. Box 70, VANCOUVER, B.C.

Kitwancool Indian Day School

A few days ago I visited Kitwancool with the intention of securing a site for a new day school among other things. I found that the Band had recently completed the clearing of approximately four acres for a new ball ground; they told me that we might have either this or the old ball grounds for the school. I feel that the old ground, although a little small (approximately 1½ acres) would be the most desirable because it is more centrally located and more accessible to water.

I believe that replacement of the present school stands high on the priority list and rightly so, but since it is doubtful if the new building will be constructed this year I must request replacement of the woodshed at the present building. The old woodshed collapsed last winter making it necessary to dig the wood out of the snow drifts. I would suggest construction of a small shed on skids so that it might be pulled to a new location if, and when, necessary. We would require 1,000 ft. of rough lumber which can be purchased from the Band saw mill at $35.00 per thousand, two rolls of 3-ply roofing paper at $4.95 each - plus labour 6 man days at $8.00. The latter should be in the form of an accountable advance. Quotation on the materials required is enclosed herewith.

J.J. BOYS
Indian Superintendent

Kitwangaol Indian Day School

It had been intended to replace this old and dilapidated building with a new one room school and teacherage this year, but it is now quite evident that it will have to be held over until 1950.

I had hesitated to request any expenditure on the old building but it now appears that since my visit last June there has been a second small fire in the building, which was unreported by Miss Skatfield. Mr. Schroeder arrived at Kitwangaol a few days ago and both he and his wife must have been somewhat discouraged by what they found.

As a result of the fire it is imperative that we do some minor roof repairs and some painting in the teacherage. The Schroeders propose to occupy only the small kitchenette and the downstairs room, both of which should be painted. This will necessitate purchase of five gallons of interior cream paint, two brushes and turpentine. The roof repairs will require 800 lbs of rough lumber at $35.00 per thousand, also ten lbs. of nails and five rolls of two-ply roofing at $4.50.

It would be appreciated if you would please let me have authority for this work with the least possible delay and also ask the Department to forward by Air Mail an Accountable Advance for $30.00 or ten man days at $3.00. The road to Kitwangaol has been undergoing repairs and is passable only while present fine weather lasts; fall rains would make it impossible to get to the reserve.

J. V. BOYS
Indian Superintendent
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

No specific provision was made in the Estimates for repairs to this School on the assumption that the building would be replaced this year.

Re: Kitwancool Indian Day School
Your File 863-5 (E1)

In previous correspondence with regard to the proposed erection of a new school at Kitwancool, Babine Agency, we intimated that we proposed to recommend the erection of a prefabricated building, but as it would appear that there may be some difficulty in securing approval for the purchase of such a building without competitive tenders, which are not immediately available, we would now recommend that the Department advertise immediately for tenders on the erection of a standard building, Plan No. 933, which, in spite of some disadvantages, we feel would be suitable for use at Kitwancool where there is no running water or electricity.

The attached Construction Report form indicates in what newspapers the advertisement should be placed and it would be appreciated if early attention could be given to this, as the construction season in that district is short.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Dear Sir,

I beg to draw your attention to the fact that up to the present date no grant has been made to the Indian School at Kishagass in the Agency of Mr. Loring, hence my letter to the Department on this occasion. The School at Kishagass has been worked by an agent of the Church Missionary Society now for over four years, but hitherto no application, as far as I am aware has been put in, in writing for a grant in aid.

I now make such application, in order that the school may be enabled to get all necessary materials, suitable furniture etc. School opened this fall, on the 1st of October, but no children attended till the commencement of the 2nd week of the quarter; however by working straight on to Christmas, we should be able to get the required number of days of attendance in.

The register is kept daily, according to directions ordered within, up to the present time there have been 35 children on the roll, but attendance is very very much amongst a hunting and trapping people. The first week of this quarter for instance we could not get any children as they were away with their parents at their potato gardens.

Now we are in full swing of work, with School open for four hours every day except Saturday and Sunday.

F. Loring, Esq.
Indian Agent.
The Teachers are my Wife and myself, who share the work of the School. I am in hopes that we shall be able to keep School going regularly right on to May, when the Indians scatter for hunting etc.

I shall be much obliged if in due time you can send me the proper School return to be filled up from the register.

Believe me; Yours Truly,

Rev. Vernon Ardagh,

Dear Sir,

At our Diocesan Synod held last week, it was decided to send one of our experienced lady missionaries to Hazelton to assist the Rev. J. Field relieving him of the Indian School work.

It is now twenty-five years ago since the Church of England began work among the Indians of Hazelton. The Rev. J. Field has been labouring there for nineteen years, teaching the Indian Day School etc., for some years he drew the Indian Department's grant for the day school but through excessive conscientiousness he has taught the Indian Day School for the last four or five years without asking for the Government grant. The Church of England has erected a fine new building for this work and the average attendance of scholars has been very fair. Now that we have decided to strengthen the school work at Hazelton we appeal to the Indian Department through you for a renewal of the Government grant. Our conference also decided to send a qualified teacher to Yishgegas, a Church of England Mission sixty miles above Hazelton where we have kept an Indian Day School for some years past, unaided by the Government except the year Dr. Ardagh taught the school there. We appeal for a day school grant for this important station on the Babine river.

We notice in the public press that there is a talk of establishing an Industrial School at Hazelton under Methodist auspices. We would most respectfully point out to the Department that Hazelton has been for 25 years a Church of England Mission and that according to the Government Census of 1904...
of 1904 there are over six hundred Church of England Indians on the Upper Skeena River, above the Canyon, and two hundred and seventy-three Methodist Indians in the same District and if the Indian Department contemplates establishing an Industrial School at Hazelton we trust that the Church of England may be accorded the privilege of securing teachers—farm instructor, &c.,

As there is no mail up the Skeena river at present I am sending this letter direct to you as Superintendent writing another with a copy of this enclosed to Mr. R.E. Loring the Indian Agent at Hazelton. The Diocese of Caledonia covers the Northern half of British Columbia.

I remain,

Yours faithfully,

"Dear Sir,

"I have forwarded your letter of July 27th to Archdeacon Collison and asked him to explain the whole matter to Jonathan Harmer.

"For the past ten years I have been working steadily towards the new policy - The Indian Department becoming entirely responsible for Indian School work, allowing the Church to impart religious instruction.

"In all the other Agencies except yours the old system has almost passed away. The Indian Department has erected fine school buildings and pays good salaries to the Indian School teachers and meets all expenses such as traveling, etc."

"At Hazelton and Gitwangak the Indian Department still makes use of our Church buildings without allowing anything in the way of rent.

"Some time ago I informed Miss Keme, the Indian Day School teacher at Gitwangak that she was to look to the Indian Department entirely for her salary, and as Church we have ceased to have any responsibility in regard to her."

"I think that the Department should erect a new school house at Gitwangak and set our school building free for Church Army meetings there, and also the school children sitting there during school hours.

"Under the old system there was divided authority, Church and State. Under the new system the Indian Department has full control which is far more satisfactory. There is the Indian Agent, the Inspector of Indian Agencies and the Indian School Inspector - all looking after these schools.

"Why I ask you to notify the Department that we require our Church building at Gitwangak for Church Army purposes and that this building is no longer suitable for school purposes.

"As I have said in nearly all our other Missions, such as Metlakatla, Kiskisith, Laxkings, etc., the Department has erected fine new school houses and there is no reason why Gitwangak should not have one also.

Dear Captain Mortimer,

I cannot tell you how pleased I was to find you so far on the way to recovery when I called on Sunday. You looked so vital that I expect to hear soon that you are back on your old stomping ground as well as ever. Indeed this is my sincere hope.

My dear Doctor:

When I called upon you at your Office in Ottawa last September, I was greatly encouraged by your kindly reception and your assurance that you would welcome any communication I sent direct to you and give it your personal attention. I am therefore taking the liberty of writing about several matters, some of which I discussed with you. I think Mr. Mallison of Hazelton told me he had written about some of them to your Department.

(1) The village of Kisagagas, about 65 miles north of Hazelton, has had no teacher there for a number of years. At one time your Department gave a grant in the neighbourhood of $500.00 towards the stipend of a teacher for these very isolated people, but for some reason this lapsed. It is a very small community and very isolated and I do not think that it is a place where a white teacher should be sent. But I have a fairly well educated Indian in Hazelton, Mr. W. Wals, who is quite capable of teaching the really only necessary things, such as reading, writing and arithmetic and is ready to undertake this. I am inclined to think that about six months per year would be all that these families would be found at home. If the Department would give a grant of $75.00 per month for these six months, it would meet the situation adequately.

(2) I also spoke to you about the village of Kitwancool, a fairly important village about eighteen miles north of Gitwangah. These people have never had a school. They were very much prejudiced against the Government
over the land question and would not allow them to even establish a school. Recently the younger men have been anxious to have a school for their children and on several occasions have approached me about the matter. Since calling upon you I have visited this place and discussed the question with them and they expressed their great anxiety to have a teacher. Mr. Mallison of Hazelton was to have visited them a couple of weeks later when they were going to put the case up to him.

At this place there is also a native, Mr. Williams, who has a more than ordinary bright mind and is fairly well educated and would be willing to undertake the work of teacher. He could not take up some of the things ordinarily taken up in schools at present, but he could teach the fundamentals as mentioned in the case of Kisagagas. As in the case of Kisagagas, I do not think any white teacher should be asked to go and live there.

Mr. Barry, I believe, thinks that in the case of Kitwancool a white teacher should be sent. I personally know this place and cannot agree with the idea.

It must be remembered that the children in both the above places cannot speak English and only one who has knowledge of their language could make any progress with them.

A grant similar to the one mentioned for Kisagagas would be sufficient for Kitwancool from October 1st to the end of March. This would cover all the time the natives could be relied upon to be at home.

I believe there would be little difficulty in getting some suitable place to carry on a school in either of the above places.

(3) On more than one occasion Mr. Barry has reported against our teacher Mr. S. Kinley of Aiyanash. On his last inspection he personally told Mr. Kinley that he would give him a good report and yet word was received later from your Office that the report
was not good.

Mr. Kinley has taken two terms at Victoria under Mr. Barry and puts himself wholeheartedly into the work of the school. He has had an unusually good average attendance of children and is highly thought of by the natives and is held in the highest esteem by myself. His influence for good in the community could not be excelled. As a matter of fact, he is outstanding among the workers among the natives. I would be extremely sorry if I did not get your assurance that he would be carried on at Aiyansh to continue his really excellent work.

One thing needed very much there is a new school where in all probability better work could be done. At present the school is held in a large room in the mission house.

(4) I got a distinct surprise a few weeks ago to hear that Mr. Barry had recommended a change in the school at Metlakatla. Mr. Bryant has been the teacher here for I think about eight years. His school has always been held up as an example of all that is fine in such schools. I have no supervision over him as I have over certain others of the teachers, but I know him well and hold him in the highest respect. As a man, a Christian and a teacher he stands the test. I believe you visited this school yourself and expressed yourself as unusually pleased with it. And I happen to know that Col. Pragnall recently visited it and made written notes upon several things which he thought to be outstanding in their excellence. The Indian Agent here has many times expressed himself of his pleasure of having such a man at Metlakatla. Mr. Barry objects to his age. I believe he is 59, and is in better health than he was when he undertook the work there. But he is at an age when if he were thrown out he would find it difficult to get anything else to do, as you so well know in these days. Unfortunately he has an invalid wife which adds seriously to his problems. I am satisfied
if you or Mr. Hoey could inspect the excellent work Mr. Bryant is doing, you would not only consent but insist upon his remaining at Metlakatla.

I am grateful that I have your assurance that I am free to write to you what I have on my mind. I have, however, told Mr. Collison, the Indian Agent here, that I was writing and what was the import of my letter.

I was not sure whether I should take up your time or that of Mr. Hoey, but I am enclosing an extra copy which could be handed over to him if you so think it wise.

With every good wish,

Yours faithfully,

G. A. Rix.

Dear Sir,

re - Suggested Indian Day School at Kisgegas.

Referring to your letter of September 10th regarding the suggestion of a day school at Kisgegas, I wish to submit the following particulars for your information:

There are approximately twelve children of school age who have not received any education.

Suitable buildings can be procured for use as school and teacher's residence at reasonable rentals, that of the school building being about $5.00 per month.

As this reserve is more than fifty (50) miles from Hazelton, over a rough mountainous trail, I am of opinion that the suggestion of the Right Reverend G. A. Rix, D. D., Bishop of Caledonia, to send an Indian Teacher there would meet the situation, if this has the approval of the Department.

As the attendance at the school would be very small I would suggest that an allowance of $50.00 per month be given the teacher for six months - or more, if necessary - each year at present.

Desks of whip-sawed lumber could be made on the reserve, it being almost impossible to ship in the regular school desks.

As to whether a day school should be established or not in this village is entirely up to the decision of the Department. Consideration as to the remoteness of this reserve; the difficulty of access to it and the impossibility of the few children there obtaining education are points in favour of a school. On the other hand it would be utterly impracticable to send a White Teacher to this reserve.

Your obedient servant,

My dear Bishop Rix:

I have for acknowledgment Your Lordship's letter of November 24th, in which you submit, for my consideration, a number of proposals with respect to the administration of Indian day schools in the diocese of Caledonia.

I may state that the employment of teachers at Indian day schools, other than those who have secured professional certificates, has, in recent years, been given a great deal of consideration by the departmental officials. We have a great deal of sympathy for a number of elderly teachers, many of whom have rendered faithful and conscientious service in our schools at a time when it was exceedingly difficult, if not impossible, to secure fully qualified teachers. It is scarcely necessary to point out, however, that there are at the present time hundreds of fully trained teachers, many of whom are university graduates, who have throughout the depression failed to secure employment. The Dominion Government, in cooperation with the Provinces, is engaged at the moment in the promotion of a programme designed to secure for the young people of the country the opportunities for useful employment to which these young people feel they are entitled. In view of this fact, it is exceedingly difficult to justify the employment of teachers lacking the ordinary qualifications. I am, personally, of the opinion that it will be impossible to secure from Parliament, during the days that lie ahead of us, money for the payment of teachers in charge of Indian day schools, other than those who have taken the regular course of training in the provincial normal schools. This subject has been discussed on a number of occasions.

of occasions by representatives of the churches with our officials, and all of these representatives have agreed that only fully qualified teachers would be recommended by them in the future. This decision may appear somewhat harsh to certain teachers now in our employment, but I cannot possibly see how any other decision can be reached.

It is my intention to review again Inspector Barry's reports covering the work of Mr. Kinley and Mr. Bryant, with the object of retaining these men at their respective schools for another year or two, at least. It may be possible in certain cases to justify the employment of teachers who lack full academic and professional standing but who have, nevertheless, rendered fairly satisfactory service over a period of years; but, to ask the Department to engage teachers not previously employed would, I am afraid, create a great deal of bitter controversy and would be scarcely fair, either to the teachers employed on the one hand or to the Department on the other. My dear Doctor:

When I called upon you at your Office in Ottawa last September, I was greatly encouraged by your kindly reception and your assurance that you would welcome any communication I sent direct to you and give it your personal attention. I am therefore taking the liberty of writing about several matters, some of which I discussed with you. I think Mr. Mallison of Hazelton told me he had written about some of them to your Department.

(1) The village of Kisgagas, about 65 miles north of Hazelton, has had no teacher there for a number of years. At one time your Department gave a grant in the neighbourhood of $500.00 towards the stipend of a teacher for these very isolated people, but for some reason this lapsed. It is a very small community and very isolated and I do not think that it is a place where a white teacher should be sent. But I have a fairly well educated Indian in Hazelton, Mr. W. Wale, who is quite capable of teaching the really only necessary things, such as reading, writing and arithmetic and is ready to undertake this. I am inclined to think that about six months per year would be all that these families would be found at home. If the Department would give a grant of $75.00 per month for these six months, it would meet the situation adequately.

(2) I also spoke to you about the village of Kitwancool, a fairly important village about eighteen miles north of Gitwangah. These people have never had a school. They were very much prejudiced against the Government
over the land question and would not allow them to even establish a school. Recently the younger men have been anxious to have a school for their children and on several occasions have approached me about the matter. Since calling upon you I have visited this place and discussed the question with them and they expressed their great anxiety to have a teacher. Mr. Mallison of Hazelton was to have visited them a couple of weeks later when they were going to put the case up to him.

At this place there is also a native, Mr. Williams, who has a more than ordinary bright mind and is fairly well educated and would be willing to undertake the work of teacher. He could not take up some of the things ordinarily taken up in schools at present, but he could teach the fundamentals as mentioned in the case of Kisgagas. As in the case of Kisgagas, I do not think any white teacher should be asked to go and live there.

Mr. Barry, I believe, thinks that in the case of Kitwancool a white teacher should be sent. I personally know this place and cannot agree with the idea.

It must be remembered that the children in both the above places cannot speak English and only one who has knowledge of their language could make any progress with them.

A grant similar to the one mentioned for Kisgagas would be sufficient for Kitwancool from October 1st to the end of March. This would cover all the time the natives could be relied upon to be at home.

I believe there would be little difficulty in getting some suitable place to carry on a school in either of the above places.

(3) On more than one occasion Mr. Barry has reported against our teacher Mr. S. Kinley of Aiyansh. On his last inspection he personally told Mr. Kinley that he would give him a good report and yet word was received later from your Office that the report
was not good.

Mr. Kinley has taken two terms at Victoria under Mr. Barry and puts himself wholeheartedly into the work of the school. He has had an unusually good average attendance of children and is highly thought of by the natives and is held in the highest esteem by myself. His influence for good in the community could not be excelled. As a matter of fact, he is outstanding among the workers among the natives. I would be extremely sorry if I did not get your assurance that he would be carried on at Aiyansh to continue his really excellent work.

One thing needed very much there is a new school where in all probability better work could be done. At present the school is held in a large room in the mission house.

(4) I got a distinct surprise a few weeks ago to hear that Mr. Barry had recommended a change in the school at Metlakatla. Mr. Bryant has been the teacher here for I think about eight years. His school has always been held up as an example of all that is fine in such schools. I have no supervision over him as I have over certain others of the teachers, but I know him well and hold him in the highest respect. As a man, a Christian and a teacher he stands the test. I believe you visited this school yourself and expressed yourself as unusually pleased with it. And I happen to know that Col. Pragnall recently visited it and made written notes upon several things which he thought to be outstanding in their excellence. The Indian Agent here has many times expressed himself of his pleasure of having such a man at Metlakatla. Mr. Barry objects to his age. I believe he is 59, and is in better health than he was when he undertook the work there. But he is at an age when if he were thrown out he would find it difficult to get anything else to do, as you so well know in these days. Unfortunately he has an invalid wife which adds seriously to his problems. I am satisfied
McGill,

if you or Mr. Hoey could inspect the excellent work Mr. Bryant is doing, you would not only consent but insist upon his remaining at Metlakatla.

I am grateful that I have your assurance that I am free to write to you what I have on my mind. I have, however, told Mr. Collison, the Indian Agent here, that I was writing and what was the import of my letter.

I was not sure whether I should take up your time or that of Mr. Hoey, but I am enclosing an extra copy which could be handed over to him if you so think it wise.

With every good wish,

Yours faithfully,

G. A. Rix.
Ottawa, August 12, 1938.

TO HIS EXCELLENCY
THE GOVERNOR GENERAL IN COUNCIL:

The undersigned has the honour to report:

THAT there are twenty (20) Indian children of school age on the Kisgegas Indian reserve, Babine agency, province of British Columbia, for whom at present no educational facilities are provided;

THAT funds are available in the appropriation for the fiscal year 1938-39, Vote 168, for the establishment of a day school on the Kisgegas reserve.

The undersigned, therefore, recommends that a day school be established on the Kisgegas Indian reserve, Babine agency, province of British Columbia, in accordance with the provisions of Section 9 (a) of the Indian Act, Chapter 38, R.S. 1927, to be known as "The Kisgegas Indian Day School".

Respectfully submitted,

Acting Minister of Mines and Resources.
Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER:

Re: Establishment of Kisgegas Indian Day School,
Kisgegas Indian reserve, Babine Indian Agency,
province of British Columbia.

There are twenty (20) Indian children of school age on the Kisgegas reserve, Babine agency, province of British Columbia, for whom at present no educational facilities are provided. This reserve is 65 miles from the nearest school.

The establishment of a school on the Kisgegas reserve has been urged for the past two years by His Lordship Right Reverend G. A. Rix, Bishop of Caledonia, and Indian Agent Mortimer, and is approved by Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for British Columbia.

In preparing the estimates for the current fiscal year, provision was made for the salary of a teacher at this place.

In order to comply with Section 9 (a) of the Indian Act, it is necessary to obtain an Order-in-Council establishing this school. I therefore enclose Memo to Council for this purpose.

Dear Sirs:

For sometime you have been good enough to provide for a seasonal school at Kisagas at a cost of $50.00 per month. This has been of great value to this very isolated Indian Community. I have been informed that the time for this school has been set at five months. While this is valuable, yet I am persuaded that seven months would quite double the value of this work. I sincerely hope you will find it possible to agree to this very small extra expenditure for next year and would be glad to hear from you about it.

Hoping for an affirmative answer, I am,

Yours faithfully,

G. A. Rix,
Bishop of Caledonia.

Dear Sir,

re- Kisgegas Seasonal School.

I wish to make a recommendation in regard to the Kisgegas Seasonal School which has, during the past, been open for five months each year, from October 1 to February 26.

During the months of January and February of this year, the total number of pupils registered at this school was twelve, and of these twelve, five were children of the teacher, William Wale, who is an Indian of the Hazelton Band, and who lives in Hazelton for the greater part of the year. Of the remaining seven, one has reached the age of seventeen, and will no longer be attending school, and arrangements can be made for another to remain in Hazelton and attend the Day School here.

This will leave only five prospective pupils for the coming term, and I would therefore recommend that the school be closed until a larger number of pupils warrants its being re-opened.

Yours faithfully,

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
Pemberton Meadows Jan 14th 1911

Mr. McDonald
Indian Agent
New Westminster B.C.

Dear Sir,

I am going to write and let you that we are going to cut some logs for the school house for our children here at Pemberton Meadows. We make an arrangement with Mr. Tom Graham at the hatchery for the lumber we are going to have in store where not started yet but are going to do this winter. We think this is better than going to have River for the lumber so we ask for the Indian Depot - went to help us for the nails and the shingles to be done. Know how much nails and shingles until we will insert the building. We want nail and shingles from Lillooet and for windows and door we want by Douglas wood next summer. We will let you know how many and doors of one other time and we want some tar paper for the floor and some paper for the wall so we all very glad to start this now for you know this are many childrens here at Pemberton Meadows so good bye I hope this letter will find in good health with best regard to you Yours Truly,

Chief James Matzie
Indian Reserve Pemberton Meadows
Sir:—

I have the honor to forward herewith a letter dated the 14th instant, received from Chief James of Pemberton band, in regard to the building of a school house for the children of the band.

Mr. T. Graham, the manager of the Dominion Government Salmon Hatchery at Pemberton, has installed a small saw-mill plant at the Hatchery, and the Indians have arranged with him to have the lumber for the school building sawed there, they furnishing the logs and paying for the sawing in labor; and they want to know if the Department will supply nails, shingles, windows, doors, etc., as well as pay the salary of a teacher when the building is completed. They will do all the necessary carpenter work, etc., in connection with the erection of the building.

The Chief states in his letter that he does not know what quantity of material will be required. From this it is evident that they have not yet decided what size building they will put up.

If the Department decides to give favorable consideration to the request made by the Indians, perhaps it would also furnish a suitable plan, and then the quantity of material required could be figured up, and an estimate of the cost of same prepared.

There are between 40 and 50 children of school age in the band, and the building would have to be sufficiently large

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
to provide living apartments for the teacher.

Some few of these Indians have been attending St. Mary's Mission Boarding School from time to time, but the others have had no opportunity of attending any school.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.
Ottawa, February 7, 1911.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 24th ultimo enclosing a communication from the Indians of the Pemberton Band in which they ask the Department for assistance to enable them to erect a school building.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will be pleased to grant this assistance provided it is assured that the building that the Indians will erect will be a substantial structure and meet the requirements. If they supply the lumber and perform the labour the Department will provide the doors, windows, shingles, tar paper and hardware, etc., and will also furnish the school-room and pay the salary of a teacher when it is ready for occupation.

The Department has no plan that would be suitable for a building of this kind, but I may state that in several sections of British Columbia the Indians have under the supervision of the Indian Agent put up suitable frame structures. It is thought that you should be able to furnish a sketch of a building that would be suitable for the purpose of the Indians and give them such instructions as will enable them to do the work. The size of the building will depend upon the number of children to be accommodated. There should be 16 square feet of floor space and 250 cubic feet of air space for each child. The floor should

R. C. McDonald, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
New Westminster, B.C.
should be well laid and there should be a porch at the entrance. If accommodation for a teacher is necessary it is thought that it would be preferable to erect a leanto unless the dimensions are such that there would be no danger of overcrowding the pupils if a couple of rooms are provided for the teacher. The Department would like you before taking final action to submit a sketch that you think would be suitable with a description of the building, and, if approved and the Indians agree to do the work in accordance with your plan, the permission to purchase the material above referred to will then be given.

I may say that it is the wish of the Department to give these Indians every encouragement.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.
Ottawa, March 27, 1911.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 18th instant in further reference to the erection of a school building by the Pemberton Band of Indians.

In reply I beg to say that if these Indians will erect a good substantial building along the lines of the sketch submitted with your letter the Department will purchase for them the shingles, doors and other articles mentioned in your letter. If you consider it necessary you may authorize the purchase of the nails, tar paper and shingles at Lillooet, in order that the Indians may get at the work earlier in the season. I have to ask you to be good enough to state what means you will have of watching building operations, or how often you will be able to visit the locality yourself. If it will not be possible for you to visit the locality at frequent intervals you should make arrangements to receive reports from some reliable person.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

R. C. McDonald, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
New Westminster, B.C.
Sir:-

Referring to your letter of the 7th ultimo, No. 380000, regarding the application made by the Pemberton band of Indians for assistance to enable them to erect a school building on their reserve, I have the honor to enclose herewith a ground floor rough sketch of the proposed building a copy of which I also sent to the Indians of the band, and they informed me that they are willing to put up such a building, provided the Department will grant them the assistance asked, and also provided the sketch meets with the approval of the Department.

A school room of the size indicated on the plan, should give sufficient floor and air space for 40 pupils, and it is not likely that there will be more than that number at any one time attending school.

The following is an estimate of the quantity of material required and the cost of same at New Westminster:

- 16 M. Shingles ........................................... $36.00
- 5 Doors .................................................. $25.00
- 5 Door Frames ............................................ $15.00
- 14 Windows ............................................... $70.00
- 14 Window Frames ....................................... $42.00
- 12 Rolls Tar Paper ....................................... $9.00

The Secretary,

Department of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa.
5 Rim Locks (complete) ........................................... $3.00
5 pairs Hinges .................................................. 1.00
100 lbs. Shingle Nails .......................................... 4.50
300 lbs. 2½ inch Nails ......................................... 10.20
100 lbs. 5 inch Nails ........................................... 3.25

Total ............................................................... $218.95

It is difficult to estimate the freight charges, as it will depend altogether as to how the material can be shipped. The Steamer Beaver usually makes one trip from her to Port Douglas in the month of May each year, carrying supplies for the store at Douglas and for the Hatchery at Pemberton; and if this material can be shipped in this way, it should not cost more than about $20.00, and the Indians would be able to take it from Douglas themselves, the distance from there to Pemberton being about 60 miles.

The Indians, however, ask that the shingles, nails and tar paper be purchased at Lillooet, as they evidently wish to commence the building before the month of May, and would not be able to get these articles in by Douglas before the latter part of May or first of June.

Sir:-

Replying to your letter of 1st October, 1915, in which you requested me to give further information with respect to the establishment of schools for the Indians at Pemberton Meadows as well as those of the Douglas tribe along the Lillooet River, the latter extending from Harrison to Lillooet Lakes, a distance of 29 miles, I beg to say that a boarding or industrial school established in the vicinity of Pemberton Meadows would serve a very useful purpose, as, at present, the Indians of these tribes are without any education facilities.

There are about 75 children of school age at Pemberton Meadows and another 75 in the various villages of the Douglas tribe. A few are at present attending the St. Mary's Mission Boarding School, at Mission City, which is distant from Pemberton Meadows approximately 120 miles and from Fort Douglas 60 miles. The largest village of the Douglas Indians is at Skookumchuck, 19 miles above Fort Douglas or 79 miles from Mission City. The Pemberton and Douglas tribes are in the New Westminster Agency but contiguous to the Pemberton band are the Anderson and Seton Lake Indians, where there are also a number of children without any school facilities.

A boarding or industrial school established somewhere

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.
somewhere near Pemberton Meadows would thus have a large field from which to obtain pupils and would thus leave the boarding school at Mission City free to take pupils from the reserves in closer proximity to that point.

When taking up the matter of establishing a school for these Indians the question of obtaining a favourable site would have to be given serious thought. The Pemberton Indians suggested a site at the head of Anderson Lake, 17 miles distant. This, no doubt, would be an ideal location were land available there, but unfortunately it is not. The Anderson Lake Indians have only about 500 acres in their four reserves and it would, therefore, not be wise to expropriate sufficient land for a school and farm which should have at least 100 acres. The Catholic church had a large tract of land at this point some time ago but sold it to the Pacific Great Eastern Railway Company. To obtain any other land in this section of the country it would have to be acquired by purchase and, no doubt, at a high figure. The location on the Pemberton Meadows would not be desirable as the lands are subject to overflow occasionally, and every summer from June until the middle of August mosquitoes are a very serious pest. These flies are so bad on the bottom lands that the Indians have to move their families and drive their cattle into the hills at times. There is, however, some good land at Pemberton Reserve No. 6 the old Smith-Bell pre-emption, on which a school might be established. This reserve is in a valley about nine miles above the Pemberton Indian village and at a much higher elevation. I am given to understand also that there is plenty of good water and is much freer from mosquitoes than the lower land. This site might be kept in mind for future consideration when the Departments feels that
that the establishment of a school in this section of the country can be taken up.

As regards physicians to treat the Indians of the Pemberton and Douglas bands I also beg to say that they are without medical attention, unless the Pemberton, on the one hand go to Dr. Christie at Lillooet, 60 miles distant, or to Dr. Paul at Squamish, 75 miles away. With the building of the Pacific Great Eastern Railway through the Pemberton Valley no doubt a number of settlers will soon go into this country who will, in all likelihood, be followed by a doctor. This, no doubt, will help the Pemberton Indians, but will be of little advantage to the Douglas Indians on the Lillooet River, as to reach the doctor at Pemberton the Indians of Samahquam, Sachteen and Skookumchuck would have to travel nine miles by wagon and 25 miles by boat up the Lillooet Lakes to reach the Pemberton Meadows. The Douglas Indians at Fort Douglas have to go down Harrison Lake 28 miles by canoe or launch and five miles by road to be treated by Dr. McCaffrey at Agassiz.

With regard to the Indians along the Douglas River I see no hope for the future of a doctor ever being in closer touch than Dr. McCaffrey is at present, for it is purely an Indian country, there being no white people in the district whatever. At Pemberton, however, the case is hopeful, for as I have already stated, there is a great probability of this section of the country being occupied in the near future by a considerable number of white settlers.

I trust the foregoing will be sufficient information for the Department to keep on file for future use when consider-
considering both the establishment of a school and also the necessity of appointing a physician to attend the Indians when the opportunity presents itself.

I herewith enclose a marked plan, showing the various points alluded to in my letter, in order that you may have a fair conception of the section of country in which the Indians live where the establishment of a school would serve a very useful purpose.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

I beg to inform you that recently I received a letter from the Chief of the Pemberton Indian Reserve No. 1, in the New Westminster Agency, asking that a day school should be erected on their reserve for the education of the Indian children of which he stated there are over fifty of school age.

On receipt of the Chief's letter I wrote to Mr. Indian Agent Daunt asking for his opinion and he has informed me that there are more children on the Pemberton reserve than can possibly be accommodated at the St. Mary's Residential School at Mission, and he would be very much in favor of a day school being provided for the Pemberton children. He further states that a Field Matron would also be of the greatest assistance. The Pemberton band have a population of just under three hundred Indians and there are about twenty children from the place now in the Mission School and there must be another forty of school age around the reserve. Providing it would be possible to accommodate all the children of the Pemberton reserve at the school at Mission, it must be remembered that there are always a certain number of the Indian children who are not physically fit to be admitted to residential schools and a day school would be the only institution at which they would have the opportunity of receiving an education.

If a day school is to be built on the Pemberton Reserve it will also be necessary to provide living quarters for a teacher and his wife, and the latter might be appointed to the position of Field Matron. The total cost of the two buildings I should think would not exceed $6,000.00.

The Pemberton Meadows on which the Indian Reserve is situated are at the head of Lillooet Lake close to the northern boundary of the New Westminster Agency.

Some time ago I wrote to the Deputy Minister furnishing him with information as to what points throughout the Province I thought our residential schools might be extended and among the points I mentioned the Lillooet district at which I thought a residential school should be established in order to take care of the education of the children of the Pemberton Meadows as well as those children in the bands in the northern part of the Lytton Agency. I have, however, heard nothing as yet that my recommendation in this regard has been put into effect and, therefore, I am of the opinion that it would be advisable to at least build a day school for the Pemberton Indians.

WED/KD.

Your obedient servant,

W. E. Dittohburn,
Indian Commissioner for B. C.

Both the Pemberton Meadows and the Tsawassen Reserves are in the New Westminster Agency. DATE OF SURVEY: In company with Mr. Indian Agent Daunt, I visited the Pemberton Reserves to undertake the field work in connection with this Report, and also the Birkenhead Hatchery, on August 27th. On September 3rd in the Indian Agent's Office in New Westminster, I completed the necessary office work.

May I take this opportunity to thank Mr. Indian Agent Daunt and Miss Dynes for the great help afforded me in carrying out the Department's wishes.

PURPOSE OF SURVEY: This survey was carried out on instructions from Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, and in accordance with the provisions of Departmental letter 155-28-1 dated June 29th, 1937.

The special question to be reported upon was the necessity or otherwise for further educational facilities for the Indian children on the Pemberton Indian Reserves, and particularly, the matter of the establishment of an Indian Day School at that point.

METHOD FOLLOWED: As mentioned above, I visited Pemberton during the period from August 26th to 28th, inclusive, and in company with Mr. Indian Agent Daunt made a thorough inspection of the site at Mile 62, P.G.E., where many partly constructed houses await completion by the Indians to whom they have been allotted. A visit was also paid to the old Pemberton Indian village and later to the Birkenhead Hatchery.

Later at the Pemberton Hotel, and in company with Mr. Indian Agent Daunt, I had a short conversation with William Pascall, Indian Secretary and Councillor, who was informed that, if and when, an Indian Day School were established at Pemberton, it would be absolutely necessary for all available Indian children to attend regularly. He further explained to this Indian Councillor that the decision with regard to the establishment of an Indian Day School rested with the officials of the Indian Affairs Branch in Ottawa, and that, while I was prepared to recommend the establishment of such a School, it must be clearly understood that the cost of said School would have to be included in the Estimates for the next financial year, and that, therefore, no immediate decision could be arrived at in the matter.

APPEARANCE AND ATTITUDE OF CHILDREN: Many of the children on the Pemberton Indian Reserves attend St. Mary's Indian Residential School, Mission City, where they, of course, receive an excellent education. It was pointed out to me by William Pascall that in addition to those children attending School at Mission City, a very large number were not receiving any education and that the Indians were very anxious to have a Day School at Pemberton.
Appearance and attitude of Children - Cont'd.

I spoke to a few children whom I happened to meet during my visit to Pemberton Reserve No. 2 but failed to obtain any worthwhile response. The children were not very well dressed and appeared somewhat uncared for. The establishment of an Indian Day School with resident teacher would, no doubt, correct this condition.

STATISTICAL ANALYSIS OF CHILDREN:-

The list of children given in the Appendix and forming part of this Report has been compiled with very great care. A list was prepared in the Indian Agent's Office, New Westminster, and a copy forwarded to the Secretary of the Indian Council at Pemberton for any necessary alterations and additions. On receipt of this revised list in the New Westminster Office, Miss Dynes was good enough to prepare the very complete tabulation now attached.

This shows the children with ages, and by families; the name of the parent being given in each case.

There are in all 159 children of school age and under registered on the Pemberton Reserves.

Of the above 159 children, there are 105 of school age, or between the ages of 6 to 16, inclusive.

Of the 105 children of school age, 38 were attending St. Mary's Indian Residential School at Mission City last year. This leaves a total of 67 children of school age not at present attending any School.

There are 54 children under 6 years of age, which gives approximately 9 children for the receiving class or Grade 1-C yearly.

RELIGIOUS TEACHING:-

The children of Pemberton are members of the Roman Catholic Church; and it would, therefore, be under the auspices of said Church that the Indian Day School, should such be established here, would be administered.

BUILDINGS AVAILABLE:-

I was unable to discover any building on the Pemberton Reserves or at Mile 62, P.G.E. which could possibly be turned into an Indian Day School.

Should it be decided to establish an Indian Day School here, I would strongly recommend the erection of a building with class-room accommodation for at least 40 pupils, and additional rooms for living accommodation of a married teacher.

SITE OF PROPOSED SCHOOL:-

Accompanied by Mr. Indian Agent Deunt I made a careful inspection of the land at Mile 62 P.G.E.

When the Subdivision was made at this point as shown in a map mentioned below, a site was tentatively
Site of Proposed School - Cont'd.

chosen for a future school but we found on examination that this site was not very suitable and would certainly require considerable clearing and grading before a School could be erected. Even then I consider that this site was originally chosen by someone unacquainted with school requirements, as there would be no suitable ground for school gardens or a playground.

By far the best site for the proposed Indian Day School would be that shown as Lot 4 and part of Lot 3, on a map entitled "Pemberton I. R. No. 10, Lillooet District, B. C., Subdivision Survey, Department of Indian Affairs 27153-28 dated March 31, 1934". Lots 3 and 4 face on the P.G.E. Railway. I consider that the School itself with teacher's residence should be located on Lot 4, which is approximately 219.5 ft. by 215.3 ft. Part of Lot 3 adjoining could well be used, when cleared, as a garden for the teacher's use and a small playground for the children.

BIRKENHEAD HATCHERY:- This Hatchery located at Owl Creek, Mile 64.3 P.G.E. has been abandoned as a hatchery, I understand, by the Fisheries Department.

Birkenhead Hatchery is about three miles by road from the proposed site of the new School. The transportation of material from the Hatchery to Mile 62 either by road or rail would be an easy matter. At Owl Creek, P.G.E. there is a spur siding capable of accommodating from six to ten freight cars. The actual distance from this spur line to the Birkenhead Hatchery buildings is not more than 200 yards.

In addition to the main hatchery building, in which there are a large number of windows and much material, there are a supervisor's house unfurnished, a bunk house partly furnished and a number of other smaller buildings. The general condition of the buildings appears to me to be quite good and the lumber, windows, etc. well worth the cost of the necessary salvage operations.

I was unable to obtain a list of the contents of the buildings but noticed a 3 K.W. electric light generator direct current Fairbanks-Morse, which is worked by a Pelton Wheel, and a small circular saw outfit worked by water power. I believe that there are also a McClary's kitchen stove and bathroom fixtures in the bunk house.

GENERAL:- Should a School be established on the site recommended at Mile 62, those Indian children who live on the new Subdivision would only have at most about a hundred yards' walk to School, while those still living in the old Pemberton village would be within one mile by road of the proposed school.

In general I consider that, from a statistical analysis of the list of children available, as well as from an actual visit to Pemberton, there is no doubt but that an Indian Day School is very badly needed in that locality.
RECOMMENDATION:— I would recommend that an ungraded Indian Day School to accommodate not less than 40 children be established as soon as possible at Mile 62 P.G.E.

I would further recommend that the schoolroom be attached to and form part of a school building which would give ample accommodation for a married couple, and leave room for a small dispensary.

It may be noted in passing that no single teacher should be placed here, but rather a married couple, where the husband, a trained teacher, might possibly instruct the children, and his wife, a trained nurse, look after medical needs of the Indians.

I further recommend that by far the greater part of the material used in building such a School as I have proposed be obtained from the Birkenhead Hatchery, should it be still possible to take over the buildings and equipment at that point.

While the local Indians would no doubt be able to do much of the construction work on the proposed School, I feel that the Department would save money (should they decide to erect such a School), by having the work done on contract.

There is far more material at the Birkenhead Hatchery than would be needed in the erection of such a School as I have recommended. I should like to suggest that when all this is necessary for the proposed School is taken and any other equipment which Mr. Indian Agent may require for any other points in New Westminster Agency, the Pemberton Indians be allowed to move windows and lumber to Mile 62 to finish the construction of new cottages at that point, which are at present unused by those to whom they have been allotted.

---

Any delay that may have occurred in the submission of this report has been due to the necessity for a very careful examination of the locality and of plans and documents in Mr. Indian Agent Daunt's Office. In accordance with the Department's instructions the survey has been made in close co-operation with Mr. Daunt. It was felt that the wishes of the Department would best be served by going into the matter as thoroughly as possible.

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

VICTORIA, B.C.

Dear Major MacKay:

In accordance with your instructions and with reference to Departmental letter 153-28-1 from the Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, dated June 29th, 1937, I have now completed an educational survey of the Pemberton Indian Reserves, New Westminster Agency.

With the assistance of Mr. Indian Agent Daunt, the field work was completed during a visit to the Pemberton Reserves from August 26th to 28th. The necessary office work was undertaken with the help of Miss Dynes during a visit to New Westminster on September 3rd.

During my visit in the Pemberton district, I inspected with some care the buildings of the Birkenhead Hatchery at Owl Creek. Owing to the absence of the local Fisheries officer it was not possible to enter those buildings which were locked, and I have no complete list of the available equipment in this Hatchery.

Whatever the Indian Affairs Branch may think of my proposals, a consideration of the list of children (attached to and forming part of this Survey Report) can only lead to the conclusion that an Indian Day School is urgently required at Mile 62, P.G.E.

I trust that the work undertaken in the preparation of the attached Survey Report will prove of value to yourself and the officials of the Indian Affairs Branch, to whom it is submitted with respect.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry.
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

Memorandum:

THE DEPUTY MINISTER:

Re: Establishment of Pemberton Indian Day School, Pemberton No. 10 Reserve, New Westminster Agency, province of British Columbia.

According to the last census, the Pemberton Band has a population of 313, of whom approximately 78 are of school age.

Pemberton reserve is situated in New Westminster Indian agency, province of British Columbia. No school facilities have previously been provided on this reserve, although, for some years past, our officers in the field have been urging the establishment of a day school.

In the current year's appropriation, funds were provided for the erection of a new school on this reserve and the Surveys and Engineering Branch is at present preparing plans for this new building.

In order to comply with Section 9 (a) of the Indian Act, it is necessary to secure an Order-In-Council establishing this school and I therefore enclose Memo to Council for that purpose.

Director.

Dear Sir:

I beg to submit herewith Inspector Barry's report on the educational survey of Pemberton Indian Reserve, New Westminster Agency, carried out by him in accordance with 153-28-1 of June 29th, 1937.

Inspector Barry recommends that an ungraded Indian Day School to accommodate not less than 40 children be established on the Indian Reserve in the vicinity of Mile 62 P.G.E. Rly. Station and, further recommends, that the building be such as to provide for a school room, a married teacher's quarters and a small dispensary. I concur in these recommendations. REPORT ON NEW WESTMINSTER AGENCY FOR THE YEAR ENDING 1944-45

Pemberton Indian Day School: This School is under the charge of Mrs. Mary Gronseth, formerly Miss Mary McDonald from the St. Regis Reserve. This teacher is quite a success. Her Inspector's reports are good and she is very popular with the Indians. The attendance has held up very well during the year, considering the number of Indians who are away from the Reserve. An average attendance of 22 was maintained out of 30 pupils on the register, which is a much better showing than would have been possible a few years ago.

A. O'N. Daunt,
Indian Agent.
REPORT ON NEW WESTMINSTER AGENCY FOR THE YEAR ENDING 1944-45.

Schools: Three Day Schools have been operated throughout the year, viz: Pemberton, Chehalis and Skwah. The fourth school at Katzie Reserve has remained closed, and the desks have been shipped to the Skeen Agency.

A. O'N. Daunt,
Indian Agent.
Repairs to Buildings - The only Departmentally owned buildings in the Agency are four Day Schools, viz:- Pemberton, Chehalis, Skwah and Katzie. These are all in fair repair, except Katzie. This latter School has been closed for two years, and most of the windows were broken by boys. We boarded them all up, so no further damage is possible. The roof is also in poor condition, and we stopped actual leaks with such material as was on hand. The desks were all shipped to Skeena Agency in January. Both Chehalis and Skwah Schools should be painted and redecorated, but it is impossible to interest people in submitting tenders at the present time. When there is more work available in the cities and towns than can be attended to, no workmen are anxious to go out in the country on jobs. The buildings will really come to no harm until after the war, but they should certainly be attended to then.

A. O'N. Daunt,
Indian Agent.

I have received a request from Mrs. S.A. Purden, R.N., our Field Matron at the Pemberton Reserve, for permission to send her two children, a boy and a girl, to the Indian Day School.

Indian Commissioner,

Dear Major MacKay:

I am forwarding herewith my report on the new Pemberton Indian Day School, New Westminster Agency, which I inspected on February 24th last.

It was very difficult to get to the school as all roads were deep in snow and no truck or taxi was available. On request, the P.O.E. Railway Co. allowed me to hire a gas speeder from Pemberton to Mile 62 and return later in the day. I later thanked the officials concerned for their cooperation.

Considering that Mr. Barre, the teacher of the new school, is new to this sort of work, I consider he has done splendidly. He is doing his very best to put into effect the many suggestions made to him when he and Miss Blank called at my office last December.

I shall try to find time after my return in June from the Queen Charlotte Islands to visit Pemberton again, but should there be any difficulty Mr. Barre has been instructed to write to the Indian Agent or myself at once.

Some painting appears to require completion when the weather makes this possible. As the Department has decided against inside toilets in Indian Day Schools, I must needs recommend the erection of a simple outside toilet for the teacher as apart from the children's toilets now constructed. These are too small and almost useless in a general sort of way, though it is quite correct to have one available in case of illness of the teacher or his family. Such an inside chemical toilet does not do away with the necessity for an outside toilet such as are in use throughout British Columbia.

Though later some work may be necessary on the inside of the school due to shrinking of lumber in general the building appears to me to be well constructed.

Several matters were brought to my attention by the teacher and Indian Agent, such as the provision of domestic supply of water by sinking a pipe with sand point, which I should recommend to a surface well, but such matters will be looked into by Mr. Indian Agent Daunt in due course. An extra copy of this letter is attached so that it may be sent with the report on the school to Mr. Daunt.

All Indian schools in the New Westminster Agency have now been inspected. The Indian Agent is to be congratulated on the present highly satisfactory condition of his schools, and I wish to thank him for the assistance he has given to me in the carrying out of my professional duties.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools, B.C.

Dear Major MacKay:

I am forwarding herewith my report on the Pemberton Indian Day School, Roman Catholic Church, New Westminster Agency, which I inspected today, November 26th.

Mr. Indian Agent Daunt was with me for this inspection.

The school now almost a year old has been very well kept by teacher and children, and the whole place was perfectly clean. Furniture and other articles in the schoolroom were properly arranged.

Mr. and Mrs Barre are to be congratulated that in such a short space of time such a good school is now in operation in this district.

The children are happy, well dressed, and clean. The teacher has very good control indeed of these pupils.

Fire drills are held, and I suggested a few minor modifications to improve these.

With the exception of the school at Chehalis all the schools in the New Westminster Agency have now been visited during the present academic year. Reports have in each case been forwarded to the Department through your office.

I have received considerable assistance from Mr. Indian Agent Daunt during my inspections in the New Westminster Agency, and he is I think to be congratulated on the fine condition of these schools.

Yours very truly,

Gerald H. Barry,

Dear Major MacKay:

I am forwarding herewith my report on the Pemberton Indian Day School, New Westminster Agency, which I inspected on October 15th last.

This school is being conducted in a very satisfactory manner; the classroom, residence, and surroundings, being all kept in a perfectly clean condition, while the children are making quite good progress.

ADLAINE NELSON Age 15 Grade 5
ALBERT NELSON Age 8 Grade 1B
EDDY SAUL Age 9 Grade 1B
CELIE BILLIE Age 9 Grade 1C

The teacher, Mr. Barre, tells me that as far as he is aware, the home conditions of these pupils were quite satisfactory. There may be some special reason why the Department should go to the expense of the education of the above children at St. Mary's Mission; but in general I trust that children with good home conditions be sent to the local Indian day school, where some fifteen more pupils can be accommodated.

I consider that the plan of some Indian parents by which small children are kept out of the day school to insure that they are taken later to St. Mary's Residential School should be discouraged. Orphans and those children who for various reasons, poor home conditions etc., the Indian Agent considers should be at a residential school might well be included in whatever plans exist at St. Mary's Mission. This is I believe the policy of the Department and Mr. Barre has been so informed.

The general standing of the Pemberton Indian Day School is good and reflects much credit on the work of the teacher and the Indian Agent.

Yours very truly,

Sir,

The Department is considering in the Estimates for 1938-39, provision for a new Day School on the Pemberton Band Reserve.

In order that we may have full information, I would appreciate an early reply to the following questions:

(1) The approximate number of children for which provision should be made.

(2) Is the site available, or will it be necessary to purchase a site? In either event, you should state the size of the site you consider necessary and the general condition of the land, viz.: whether level or sloping. You should also mention the direction in which you consider the building should face.

(3) Will it be necessary to provide living quarters for the teacher, in connection with the School?

(4) Can drinking water be easily obtained on the site recommended by you?

(5) Would you recommend construction by contract or by day labour?

(6) Do you consider a full basement advisable?

In addition to the information requested above, you should also give any particulars that would assist the Department in planning the building. It is hoped that your reply will be both detailed and definite, in order that further correspondence will not be necessary.
In connection with the proposed School on this Reserve, I understand that Inspector Savoy discussed the matter with you when he made a survey of the Pemberton Reserve on August 27th. For your information, I might add, that Mr. Savoy considered that provision should be made for 40 children, and sufficient accommodation should be provided to enable the employment of a married couple.

Yours truly,

NEW WESTMINSTER, B.C.,
November 2nd, 1934

Your Reference No. 153-38-1.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter dated the 25th of October, regarding the proposed Day School at Pemberton Indian Reserve, and submit the following answers to the questions contained therein:

(1). There are sixty-seven (67) children of school age on the Reserve, apart from thirty-eight (38) in Residential Schools. The number is too great for one teacher to handle, so I submit the proposed school should accommodate as many pupils as the Department feel one teacher can successfully instruct. I would say, not more than forty (40).

(2). The Site recommended in the Report of the School Inspector, Lots 3 and 4, Pemberton No. 10 Indian Reserve, Subdivision, Department File No. 57153-38, dated March 31st, 1934, is available without charge, as the Lots, in question, were laid out with the intention of their eventual use for public purposes. These Lots are quite level, but somewhat rough and will need grading. The light brush with which they are covered can be easily cleared. As will be seen from the subdivision plan, these Lots front on the Pacific Great Western Railway tracks, so I think the proposed building should face that way also.

(3). Yes, living quarters for a married teacher should be attached to the school building. One heating plant would thus suffice. From the isolated nature of the place, a male teacher should be employed, and it would be a great advantage to have his wife as Field Matron, if a satisfactory combination can be found.

(4). Good water can be obtained from a well, probable depth about twelve feet. This would be less costly than a pipe line from the Birkenhead River, which would entail probably 1,000 feet of pipe besides the labour.

SIR:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter dated the 24th of February, regarding the Site of the proposed Day School at Pemberton.

The proposed Site consists of Lots 3 and 4 Pemberton No. 10 Indian Reserve, as shown on Department Plan No. 119, File No. 37332-6. These Lots are bounded on the North West by the Right-of-Way of the Pacific Great Eastern Railway and on the East by the Government Road from D'Arcy to Pemberton. Creekside Station is almost directly in front of Lot 2. The flat on which the sub-division is laid out is level, with, of course, small inequalities here and there, which could be easily filled with a Scraper. The surface soil might be described as a sandy loam and the sub-soil as all river gravel. The Bakerhead River flows past about 300 yards from the proposed site. It is a swift river and I imagine protection work on a pipe intake would be fairly costly, as in addition to the necessary length of line to obtain a flow of water by gravitation, this intake would have to be well protected from erosion. I, therefore, suggested a well, to begin with at any rate.

The small brush and bush on the Lots will be easily cleared, and I have today been advised by the Band Secretary that the young men have promised to do so as soon as the snow goes, which will be in about ten days or so. This will be without charge. With the gravel sub-soil drainage should be good, and would require no attention other than for sanitary and house purposes.

So far as the orientation of the building is concerned, as the Lots front on the Pacific Great Eastern Railway Company's tracks, I think it would look better to have the School face that way also.

Your obedient servant,

A.O.N. Daunt,
Indian Agent.

It has since been found possible to reduce the cubic area of the building somewhat and it is probable that if carried out by contract the cost of the project would not exceed $6,400.00. Hence an additional amount of $1,400.00 would be required to be provided.

I should be glad if you would advise what your Branch wishes in regard to this building.

Director.
Memorandum:

MR. HARDIE

Re: Day School and Teachers' Residence,
Pemberton Indian Reserve,
Kamloops Indian Agency, B.C.

With reference to your memorandum of March 9th, it is noted that you estimate the cost of the above-mentioned building at $6,400.00. Funds to this amount will be available in our 1938-39 appropriation and I would appreciate your completing arrangements for the erection of this building. With reference to the last paragraph of your memorandum of February 21 requesting certain information regarding the building site Indian Agent Daunt writes as follows:

"The proposed site consists of Lots 3 and 4 Pemberton No. 10 Indian Reserve, as shown on Department Plan No. 119, File No. 37532-6. These Lots are bounded on the North West by the Right-of-Way of the Pacific Great Eastern Railway and on the East by the Government Road from D'Arcy to Pemberton. Creekside Station is almost directly in front of Lot 2. The flat on which the subdivision is laid out is level, etc., or course, small inequalities here and there, which could be easily filled with a Scraper. The surface soil might be described as a sandy loam, and the sub-soil is all river gravel. The Rickenhead River flows past about 300 yards from the proposed site. It is a swift river and I imagine protection work on a pipe intake would be fairly costly; as an addition to the necessary length of line to obtain a flow of water by gravitation, this intake would have to be well protected from erosion. I, therefore, suggested a well, to begin with at any rate.

"The small brush and bush on the Lots will be easily cleared, and I have today been advised by the Land Secretary that the young trees have promised to do so as soon as the snow goes, which will be in about ten days or so. This will be without charge. With the gravel sub-soil drainage should be good, and would require no attention other than for sanitary and house purposes.

"As far as the orientation of the building is concerned, as the Lots front on the Pacific Great Eastern Railway Company's tracks, I think it would look better to have the school face that way also."

Director.

Dear Mr. Daunt:

It is after my experience to have to chase away animals away from the new school building. So that a fence would not only protect the school but it would serve as a school yard once the stumps are removed. I therefore ask you to make provision for a fence as soon as the weather permits.

A well near the school house where the children could secure drinking water would be an inexpensive convenience. However, to secure water for household purposes one must travel a hundred yards in the snow to the storekeeper's well and then manipulate a temperamental pump.

The toilet provision for the school are at present taken care of by two outside toilets, one assigned to the boys and one to the girls. Because of the prevalence of tuberculosis the teachers cannot very well use these. So that I believe that an inside chemical toilet would be needed. To this end I add a sink and siphon tank for the disposal of kitchen waste. It is a long way from the kitchenette through the school vestibule down the steps to the level ground outside.

The above are more urgently needed because of the fact that your teacher will be married within a few weeks.

I trust that you will provide for this at your earliest convenience.

Yours very truly,

J.M. Barry.
Ottawa,
February 14, 1939.

Dear Sir:

With reference to the letter dated January 17 from the teacher of the Pemberton Indian day school please let me know the cost of erecting a fence at this school, also the cost of digging a well and supplying a pump. As funds are almost completely assigned it is impossible to consider these expenditures between now and the end of March but if you consider the above-mentioned improvements necessary funds will be available after April 1.

You may secure a chemical toilet for the teacher's living quarters. It is understood that this will be purchased at as reasonable a cost as possible.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

A. O'N. Daunt, Esq.,
