SIR:-

I beg to forward you herewith, Requisition for School Material received from J.W. Barre, Teacher of the Pemberton Indian Day School.

With regard to the stationery and books requested by him, I would recommend that these be supplied from the Government Stationery office.

The Teacher's desk and chair are certainly needed, and I would recommend that an order be placed for their delivery to the School.

I have obtained prices locally for the following items shown in the requisition:

| Item                        | Price |
|-----------------------------|-------|
| Cupboard and shelving       | $20.00|
| Flag Pole                   | $15.00|
| Thermometer                 | $1.10 |
| Water Tank                  | $5.20 |
| Two Door Mats               | $1.60 |
| One Clock for School room   | $2.25 |
| One Pail                    | $.50  |
| Fire Extinguisher           | $1.25 |
| Shovel                      | $2.00 |
| Axe                         | $.30  |
| Scrub Brush                 | $.70  |
| Mop                         | $1.00 |
| Two Pails                   | $4.00 |
| Six Blinds for Class-room   | $4.00 |
| One Dust Pan                | $1.00 |

I have talked all these things over with the Teacher, and I consider that they are all necessary. It must be remembered that there is no running water in the School, so it is imperative that we have a sanitary tank to contain a supply for the children's daily use.

With regard to the item of kleenex, some provision must be made for handkerchiefs, hence the inclusion of this item, possibly paper towels would do, but they are very stiff, and kleenex would undoubtedly be better.

Mr. Barry also requests that a kitchen sink be provided in the living quarters. This appears to me to be absolutely necessary, as it is obviously unsanitary to throw dish water out around the building. I would, therefore,

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.
therefore, recommend that a sink be installed connected with a rock pit to drain the water away, and that a house force pump be installed on the premises. The prices, I have obtained locally are as follows:

- House Force Pump ........................................ $6.50
- 40 Feet of pipe in 4ft. lengths complete ............. $7.50
- Sandpoint .................................................. $2.85
- White enamel kitchen sink ................................ $5.50
- Sink drop and collar ....................................... $3.20
- Lumber to enclose sink .................................... $5.00
- Labour putting up pump and sandpoint ................ $10.00
- Labour re sink and cesspool .............................. $20.00

$80.55

The School Lot should also be fenced, in order to keep cattle away from the building, as they roam wild through the woods, and hogs are also plentiful. The figures in connection with this are as shown below:

- 70 Rods-medium weight stock fencing,
  42 inches high—(E.Gates & Stanley) ................... $75.00
- 120 Posts, crosspieces etc. (made and put into the ground) .......... $30.00
- Labour putting up the stock fencing .................. $30.00
- Labour clearing the underbrush ......................... $25.00

$160.00

The School should also have an outside toilet for the Teacher and his wife, the present arrangement merely taking care of the Indian pupils, and there certainly should be provision made for the Teacher. The cost of this will be $25.00.

The School Inspector wants a flag pole erected, and the cost of the pole erected will be $15.00. If this latter item is authorized, a flag should be sent to the Teacher.

Most of the labour in connection with this work will be performed by the Indians.

I may say that Mr. Barre appears to be shaping well as a Teacher, and I think his requests are entirely reasonable, so I trust that the Department will be in a position to grant them.

The total of these local expenditures will come to $334.45, as listed above.

Your obedient servant,

A.O.N. Daunt.

AIR MAIL

Dear Sir:

The Department understands that a teacher's desk and chair are required at the Pemberton Indian day school. Please arrange for the immediate purchase of a desk and a non-tilting chair and forward them to the teacher.

As the total cost will not exceed $50.00 it is unnecessary to secure a special encumbrance requisition. When you have made the purchase you should certify the account and forward it for payment.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Major D. M. MacKay,

P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.
Ottawa,

Dear Sir:

With reference to certain items of equipment required at the Pemberton Indian day school I enclose for your information a copy of a letter of today's date forwarded to Commissioner Mackay.

You may purchase the quantity of chloride of lime, dustbane and toilet paper which you consider is required at this school. The books and writing paper are being ordered from the Stationery Office.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

- Chair
- Visitor's chair
- Reading Ex. Bk.
- Writing "
- Fire extinguisher
- Carbolic
- Lime (Chloride of)

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 21st instant with reference to an expenditure of $100.00 for removal of stumps and levelling the school grounds at the Pemberton Indian Day School.

There are no funds available for this work at the present time. It is felt that the Indians should be sufficiently interested in the operation of the school to do a considerable amount of this work without expense to the Department. The Agent and teacher should be requested to encourage them to do so.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Major D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70,
Vancouver, B.C.
Dear Sir:

Enclosed is an application received from Mr. Indian Agent Daunt of the New Westminster Agency to expend the sum of $100 for removal of stumps and levelling of the school grounds at the Pemberton Indian Day School, in connection with which he stated that Mr. Spetch was the only man in the vicinity with the necessary equipment to do this work.

I wrote to Mr. Daunt on the 14th instant requesting to be advised if this work could not be undertaken by Pemberton Indians, as per attached copy. I enclose herewith his reply of the 15th instant informing me that he took up the matter with the only Indian accustomed to this type of clearing but he declined to perform the work in view of the proximity to the school buildings and the necessity of using powder.

It would appear that the only other course to adopt is by the use of the heavy caterpillar tractor, Mr. A. W. Spetch apparently being the only person in the locality with such equipment. Under the circumstances, I would agree to the employment of white labor if and when the funds become available and would recommend that the application have favorable consideration.

Yours faithfully,

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.
Dear Sir:

Your Ref. No. 15/5561.

In reply to your letter of May 14th, regarding the removal of stumps and levelling of school grounds, at Pemberton, I beg to say that as I stated in my application, Mr. Spetch is the only person in the vicinity, with the necessary equipment to perform this work.

It was first put up to Councillor Baptiste Ritchie, who is accustomed to taking logging contracts, and to the heavy work incidental to land clearing. He refused to have anything to do with powder work so close to the school buildings, and I think he was right. Mr. Spetch's heavy caterpillar tractor is the only way this work can be done in a safe and satisfactory manner.

Yours truly,

A.O.N. Daunt,
Indian Agent.

Major D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.
May 14, 1940.

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 10th instant applying to spend $100.00 for the removal of stumps and levelling of school grounds at the Pemberton Indian Day School, I would advise that this appears to be work that could be undertaken by the Pemberton Indians.

As you are aware, it is the Department's policy to have such work of this nature performed by Indians and would appreciate your advice on this point.

Yours faithfully,

For D.M. Mackay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

A.O'N.Daunt, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Dear Sir:

I beg to forward you herewith, a Tender received from Mr. A.W. Spetch for the removal of some twenty stumps and the levelling of the School Grounds at the Pemberton Indian Day School, at a cost of One Hundred ($100.00) Dollars.

Mr. Spetch is the only man in the vicinity with the necessary equipment to do this work.

I do not know whether the Department can provide any funds for this work, but the proper clearing and grading of the grounds would provide a place for the children to play football and other games, and I would recommend that, if possible, the work be done this Summer.

Yours truly,

A.O.N. Daunt.
Indian Agent.

Last week the Indians under the lead of Joe Lester cleared some fifteen stumps from the school yard. This work was planned last fall but was delayed till now because of the early snow. The levelling will be finished as soon as the weather permits.

I would suggest sowing three or four pounds of grass seeds to keep out the thistles which grow profusely here.

Last year the children helped me plant several trees and shrubs. This year, I am planning a school garden. So I would like to have a few seeds, as also one hoe and one rake.

Dear Mr. Daunt:

As I have had several chimney fires, I have asked the local carpenter, Mr. Gronseth, to give me an estimate on the cost of building a three section ladder to reach the chimney and roof. The lower section could be used to handle window screens and storm windows. We have no ladder for this purpose.

Because the roof shingles are weathered, the shingles are covered with fuzz which easily ignites from chimney sparks on dry frosty days. Such a ladder would make it possible to extinguish such fires, as well as fires which might be caused by forest fire sparks.

Such a ladder is deemed a necessity here as it would greatly minimize the fire hazards for this school. Please tell me what can be done regarding this matter.

With best wishes for a Happy New Year,

Sincerely yours,

J.M. Barre

I enclose herewith Mr. Indian Agent Daunt's letter of June 26th in connection with cleaning and painting required at the Pemberton Indian Day School at an estimated cost of $47.50. Major D. M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, Vancouver, B.C.

Mrs. Mary Gronseth, teacher at the Pemberton Indian Day School, has requested that some painting be done to the school entrance porch, and that the cloakrooms be varnished and floors, walls, and ceilings washed down and waxed and varnished as required. She points out that the entrance is close to the railway track, and within a few yards of where the Sleeper and Chair Car stand when the South-bound train is at the station.

We did not place an item in this Year's estimates, as the school is only Five years old, and in the ordinary way, can do without such work at the moment. It will be no harm, however, to smarten up the appearance from the train, and if Funds are available I would recommend that the amount of $47.50 be allowed, made up as follows:

2 gals. Varnish....... $11.80
1 " Paint........ 5.00
1 " Porch Paint... 1.50 $18.30

Labour, Painting, 24 hours, @ 80¢........ 19.20

$47.50

Mr. F. Grist, the Teacher at the Pemberton Indian Day School, has applied to me for curtains for six windows in the Teacher's living quarters there. He informs me that the building is close to the road, and there is no privacy with people passing back and forth.

We have looked into the matter of price in connection with these curtains, and on sale in one of the Department stores here last week, was a very good material for ninety-five (95¢) cents a yard. I had the bolt put away, as any other material would run too high, and this is very good material for the price asked, and should stand up well.

The following is the quotation given to me by the store:

27 Yards Drapery @ 95¢------------------$25.65
6 Pairs making @ $1.00----------------- 6.00
------------------------------------- $31.65

In view of the reasonable price asked for the curtains, and the fact that the windows are very bare without them, I would recommend that the sum of $31.65 be authorized for the purchase of these curtains for use at the Pemberton Indian Day School Teacher's quarters.

J. Gillett,
Indian Agent.

As you are aware, a sum of $3,500.00 has been included in our 1947-8 estimates for the construction of an additional classroom at the Remberton Indian Day School. Re: School Construction Program

I am enclosing confirmation of my Army Signals message of today's date recommending certain transfers of funds for the proposed construction at Bella Bella and Pemberton.

With regard to Bella Bella, apparently $10,000 was provided in the Estimates, reference Mr. Neary's letter of June 21st and in my letter of July 6th I recommended that the $14,000 appropriated for construction at the North Thompson Reserve be transferred to Bella Bella, making a total of $24,000. This amount, with an additional $4,000 from the amount appropriated for construction at Hazelton, a total of $28,000, should I think be sufficient to meet the cost of erecting a two room prefabricated school with accommodation for the teachers.

In the case of Pemberton School, in Mr. Neary's letter of June 21st (file 1-1-5 E), it is stated that $10,000 was provided for an addition. $18,000 should be transferred from the appropriation for the construction at Hazelton and added to this amount, a total of $28,000, which will I believe be sufficient.

The balances remaining of the funds appropriated for various schools which we do not contemplate constructing this year are as follows:

Hazelton $18,000
Fort Babine 7,000 (approx. $1,000 transferred to Kitkatle)
Our estimate of the cost of construction at Klemtu is in excess of the amount appropriated as is the estimate for construction at Anaham and other projects may cost more than the amounts specifically provided in view of which other transfers will likely be necessary at a later date.

I may say I have hesitated to make a recommendation involving transfer of funds from the amount appropriated for construction at Hazelton but at the same time do not wish to delay construction elsewhere to find at a later date that construction at Hazelton will not be proceeded with because of some alternative for the provision of educational facilities for the Indian children or for any other reason. It is hoped that a decision may be reached in the near future with respect to the Department's policy at Hazelton but in the meantime I doubt whether it would be advisable to conserve the funds appropriated.

Certified to be a true copy of a Minute of a Meeting of the Committee of the Privy Council, approved by His Excellency the Governor General on the 22 September 1948.

The Committee of the Privy Council have had before them a report dated September 14, 1948 from the Minister of Mines and Resources, representing:

That it is immediately necessary, and funds are provided in the 1948-49 estimates, Indian Affairs Branch, Mines and Resources, to provide a two-room Indian day school with attached teachers' residence on the Pemberton Indian Reserve, in the New Westminster Indian Agency, Province of British Columbia;

That it is essential that educational facilities be provided for the Indian children on the Pemberton Indian Reserve;

That Section 36 of the Public Works Act, Chapter 166, R.S.C. 1927, provides in part as follows:

"Whenever any works are to be executed under the direction of any Department of the Government the Minister having charge of such Department shall invite tenders by public advertisement for the execution of such works except in cases (a) of pressing emergency in which delay would be injurious to the public interest ..........";

That, due to the very isolated situation of this reserve, there are no builders or contractors in the area nor are outside contractors interested in tenders if invited as aforesaid, as they have all the work they can do in their own localities;

That a competent building company, namely Prefabricated Structures, Limited, Post Office Box 489, Vancouver, British Columbia, has agreed to undertake the provision of a prefabricated two-room school with attached teachers' residence immediately on a basis of $9,750.00 f.o.b. Vancouver, plus freight and erection supervisor's wages, fare and expenses;

That it is considered that the provision of this school is a pressing emergency and within the exception provided in Section 36 above recited and further, it is considered that the work can be more expeditiously and economically executed as suggested herein.

The Committee, therefore, on the recommendation of the Minister of Mines and Resources, advise that authority be granted to enter into a contract with Prefabricated Structures, Limited, for the provision of this building as outlined above, this being the only arrangement possible at the present time and it being essential that this work be undertaken at once and carried to completion in order that the building will be available for use by the time the Christmas school term commences.

The Honourable,
The Minister of Mines and Resources

Re: Proposed new school at Pemberton

With reference to Mr. Phelan's letter of October 4th, and in particular the reference to arrangements for the erection of the above mentioned school, as with other schools being built this year we have experienced considerable difficulty in securing a reasonable proposal. Superintendent Gillett contacted various contractors with a view to securing from them firm bids on the erection and completion of this building but the only tender received, that of Wallace Construction Company Limited attached, is in my opinion too high.

We have however, a proposal from Mr. R.G. Goodrich of Chilliwack regarding the erection and completion of the building on a cost plus 10% of labour for supervision basis. Mr. Goodrich in his letter of October 21st attached estimates labour costs on all phases of the work apart from clearing and excavating the site, to which estimate would have to be added the cost of additional building materials required and wiring, plumbing and heating equipment and materials.

I would mention at this time that we have carefully considered what modern facilities should be provided at this school and inasmuch as the new building will provide along with the old school a three classroom set up at this point with three teachers, it is considered that arrangements should be made for the installation of a small generating plant and inside plumbing facilities in the teacherage portion of the new building. Although there is a water supply system on the reserve the head is not great enough to supply water by gravity to the school. The water table on the Pemberton reserve is...
quite high and it is anticipated that water can be secured by digging a well at the school, which with an automatic water pressure system operated from the generating plant referred to above will permit of the installation of a flush toilet, bath, etc., in the teachers' room.

It will take some time to secure information with respect to the exact cost of the additional materials, plumbing, heating and lighting fixtures, the proposed lighting plant and the water pressure system and rather than delay a submission to Council pending receipt of this information, these costs have been roughly computed in this office. The following is a breakdown of the anticipated cost of erection and completion of this new school at Pemberton, some allowance having been made for an increase in the labour costs estimated by Mr. Goodrich, his estimate on the basis of our experience with prefabricated buildings being too low:

(1) Excavation and clearing school site.................. $500.00

I have authorized Mr. Gillett to have this work done with a bulldozer which is at Pemberton at the moment but will be returned to Vancouver in the near future.

(2) Cost of prefabricated building.......................... $10,371.00

(3) Labour based on Mr. Goodrich's estimate, which is considered to be low, plus $1,000.00.................. $7,000.00

10% of labour supervision................................. $700.00

(4) Plumbing fixtures and materials ....................... $400.00

(5) Material for foundation, etc........................... $1,500.00

(6) Wiring material and fixtures.......................... $400.00

(7) Furnace, pipes, etc.................................... $500.00

(8) Lighting plant for both schools. Cost of this item will depend entirely on the type and size of plant required which has yet to be determined but should not under any circumstances exceed $3,000.00

(9) Automatic water pressure system ....................... $200.00

(10) Freight, contingencies, etc............................ $25.00

$28,500.00
I would recommend that the Department's submission to Council be based on the above mentioned breakdown and would appreciate being advised at the earliest possible date if Mr. Goodrich's proposal is accepted and if the work may be proceeded with.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Under authority of P.C. 4224 of September 22nd, 1948, a purchase order has been placed with Prefabricated Structures Limited, Vancouver, B.C., for the provision of a prefabricated two room school with attached teachers' residence for the above Indian Reserve.

This building will cost $9,750.00 f.o.b. Vancouver.

Mr. Indian Commissioner Arneil has been endeavouring to obtain tenders locally for the necessary excavation, construction of basement, erection of frame work, walls and roof of this building. He has been only able to interest two contractors. Their tenders are as follows:

(1) R.C. Gooderich, 226 Wellington Avenue, Chilliwack, B.C. ......................... $4,510.00
(This is an estimate based on cost plus 10%)

(2) Wallace Construction Co., 1107 Royal Avenue, New Westminster, B.C. ................. $7,891.00
(This is a tender of $6,391.00 plus a fee of $1,500.00)

...........2
Mr. Indian Superintendent Gillett and Mr. Indian Commissioner Arneil have recommended the acceptance of Mr. Gooderich's tender.

While this tender does not include painting, plumbing, heating, etc., Mr. Gooderich is prepared to undertake this other work in the form of sub-contracts.

I would recommend, therefore, that the Minister accept Mr. Gooderich's tender for the erection of this school on a cost plus 10% basis in an estimated amount of $4,510.00.

Acting Director.

2. SUCCESSORS AND ASSIGNS.

This contract shall endure to the benefit of all and shall be binding upon the heirs, executors, administrators or successors and assigns (subject as hereinafter provided) of the Contractor and the successors of His Majesty; provided that the Contractor shall not be entitled to assign or sublet this contract or any of the work except as herein expressly provided.

3. QUALITY OF WORK.

The work shall be performed by the Contractor using the best materials and finished in the best and most workmanlike manner, and in strict conformity with the contract, and to the complete satisfaction of the Indian Agent and the Minister, and at such places as the Indian Agent shall, from time to time, direct.

4. TIME.

Time shall be deemed to be material and of the essence of this contract.

5. CHANGES IN THE WORK.

The Minister may, through the Indian Agent from time to time, by written instruction or drawings issued to the Contractor, make changes in the work, issue additional instructions, require additional work or direct the omission of work previously ordered, and the provisions of the contract shall apply to all such changes, modifications and additions with the same effect as if they were embodied in the contract plans, drawings and specifications.

Instructions shall be deemed to have been duly given to the Contractor if given to the Superintendent or to a foreman of the Contractor on the work, or if given to the Contractor personally or, if the Contractor is a firm or corporation, to a member of such firm or officer of such corporation.

If there is any change in the work, the Minister shall decide if there has been such a material increase or decrease in the scope of the work so that an adjustment should be made in the Contractor's fee and the Minister's decision on the adjustment to be made shall be final.
6. INDIAN AGENT SOLE JUDGE OF WORK AND MATERIALS.

The Indian Agent shall be the sole judge of the work and material, in respect of both quality and quantity, and his decision on all questions in dispute with regard thereto, or as to the meaning or intention of the contract and as to the meaning or interpretation of the plans, drawings, or specifications shall be final, and no work under the contract shall be deemed to have been performed, nor materials or things provided, so as to entitle the Contractor to payment therefor unless and until the Indian Agent is satisfied therewith, as evidenced by his certificate in writing, which certificate shall be a condition precedent to the right of the contractor to be paid therefor; provided that any such decision may be altered or cancelled by the Minister.

7. WORK SUBJECT TO CONTROL OF INDIAN AGENT.

The work shall, in every particular, be under and subject to the control and supervision of the Indian Agent.

8. FOREMAN OF WORKS.

A competent foreman shall be kept on the ground by the Contractor during working hours, to receive the orders of the Indian Agent. Such foreman shall be considered as the lawful representative of the Contractor and shall carry out all requisitions and instructions of the Indian Agent.

9. DEFECTIVE WORK OR MATERIAL.

Should the Contractor use or employ or intend to use or employ, any material, plant, tools equipment, articles or things, which, in the opinion of the Indian Agent, are not in accordance with the provisions of the contract or are in any way unsuitable for the work, or any part thereof, or should the Indian Agent consider that any work is for any reason, improperly, defectively, or insufficiently executed or performed, the Indian Agent may order the Contractor to remove the same, and to use and employ proper material, plant, tools, equipment, articles and things or to properly re-execute and perform such work, as the case may be, and thereupon the Contractor shall immediately comply with such orders and if the Contractor fails to comply with such orders within twenty-four hours the Indian Agent may, at any time thereafter, execute or cause to be executed the orders so given.

10. CONSUMABLE TOOLS, MATERIALS AND SUPPLIES.

All usable tools (other than tools customarily provided by tradesmen) and all consumable materials and supplies left over after the completion of the work shall, if the Minister so desires, be taken over and be paid for by the Contractor at a fair and reasonable price to be determined by the Minister.

11. WORK NOT COMPRISED IN CONTRACT.

His Majesty may, at any time, without payment therefor, send and employ on, in and about the work other contractors, and workmen, with such horses, machinery, tools, plants, equipment, materials, articles and things as the Indian Agent may deem necessary to do any work not comprised in the contract, and the Contractor shall afford them all reasonable facilities, to the satisfaction of the Indian Agent, for doing such work, the work of the Contractor being interfered with as little as the Indian Agent may deem practicable.
The taking of possession of the whole or any part of the work of the Contractor for such purpose shall not be deemed in acceptance by or on behalf of His Majesty of the whole or any portion of the work comprised in this contract.

contract may be used, exercised and enjoyed by His Majesty, for the purpose of carrying out the work as fully to all intents and purposes as they might theretofore have been used, exercised and enjoyed by the Contractor.

13. INSURANCE.

(a) The Contractor, unless otherwise instructed by the Minister shall insure all materials, equipment and the Contractor's plant during transit and at all times during the construction and until the final acceptance of the work and shall keep the same and all buildings and structure being constructed and/or erected insured against loss by fire, in such insurance company or companies and in such amount or amounts as may be approved by the Indian Agent and the policies of such insurance shall be made payable as the interests of the Contractor and His Majesty, respectively, appear, and the original policies together with certified copies thereof shall be forwarded to the Indian Affairs Branch; provided that such buildings or structures need not be insured by the Contractor from and after the date of the occupation thereof by His Majesty.

(b) The Contractor shall maintain such insurance as will protect him from claims under the Workmen's Compensation Acts and from any other claims for damages for personal injury, including death, which may arise from his operations under the Contract. Certificates of such insurance shall be forwarded to the Indian Affairs Branch.
and shall be subject to their approval as to adequacy of protection; and the Contractor shall indemnify and save harmless His Majesty from and against all claims and demands, loss, costs, damages, actions suits or other proceedings by whomsoever made, brought or prosecuted in any manner based upon, occasioned by, or attributable to any such death, or injury, or any damage to, or infringement of, any property or right.

14. GOVERNMENT ISSUE

(a) All items comprised in any Government issue supplied to the Contractor for the purposes of the contract shall always be and remain the property of His Majesty and shall be used by the Contractor solely for the purposes of the contract and the Contractor shall account fully to the minister for such Government issue in such manner as the Minister may require.

(b) The Contractor shall be responsible for and shall indemnify His Majesty for all loss or damage of or to any and all such Government issue while on the premises of or in the care or subject to the control of the Contractor and shall at its own expense replace, repair or restore to the complete satisfaction of the Minister any and all such Government issue which may be so lost or damaged; provided that the Contractor shall not be obligated to make good damage caused by reasonable wear and tear or due to causes beyond his control.

15. PRECAUTIONS AGAINST FIRE

The Contractor shall take special precautions to prevent fire occurring in or about the work, and shall observe and comply with all laws and regulations in force respecting fires, and with all regulations and instructions made and given from time to time during construction, by the Indian Agent with respect to fires and the prevention and extinguishing of fires.

16. ASSIGNMENTS

The Contractor shall not assign or sublet the contract without the written consent of the Minister first obtained; provided however, that (unless, in any case, the Minister objects thereto and subject also as herein provided) the Contractor may sublet such portions of the work herein contracted for as is customary and usual in the construction on such work, but His Majesty shall not in any way be held liable for the payment of any moneys due to any sub-contractor, and the Contractor shall be held responsible for the proper performance of every portion of the work herein contracted for.

17. SUB-CONTRACTORS

The Contractor shall, before entering into any sub-contracts for work or materials, notify the Indian Agent in writing of the names of all such proposed sub-contractors and the terms and conditions of such sub-contracts and shall not enter into any such sub-contracts without obtaining the approval of the Indian Agent thereto.

The Indian Agent may, on request, furnish to any sub-contractor wherever practicable, evidence of the amounts certified to on his account.

The Contractor agrees to bind every sub-contractor by the terms of the General Conditions, Drawings and Specifications, as far as applicable to his work.
18. MEMBER OF H. OF C. NOT TO BENEFIT

No member of the House of Commons of Canada shall be admitted to any share or part of the contract, or to any benefit to arise therefrom.

19. ACCOUNTS

The Contractor shall keep proper accounts and records in such form and detail as shall be satisfactory to the Minister of the cost to the Contractor of the work and the invoices, receipts and vouchers relating thereto, and such accounts, records, invoices, receipts and vouchers shall at all times be open to audit and inspection by the Minister or his authorized representatives (who may make copies thereof and take extracts therefrom) and the Contractor shall afford all proper facilities for such audits and inspections and shall furnish the Minister and his authorized representative with all such information as he or they may from time to time require with reference to such accounts, records, invoices, receipts and vouchers. If any part of the work is performed by an allied firm (as defined herein) the Contractor shall also cause such allied firm to keep similar accounts, records, invoices, receipts and vouchers with respect to the cost of the work performed by such allied firm and to permit the same to be inspected and audited by the authorized representatives of the Minister. The Contractor shall cause all such accounts, records, invoices, receipts and vouchers as aforesaid to be preserved and kept available for audit and inspection at any time and from time to time until the expiration of five (5) years from the date of the termination of the work.

20. WORK TO BE FREE FROM ALL ENCUMBRANCES

Before making any payment on any progress or final estimate the Minister may require the Contractor to furnish evidence that all work performed, and material supplied and all structures built for which payment is being made are free and clear from all lawful claims or liens under any law for labour, workmanship, materials or otherwise; the Contractor shall indemnify and hold harmless His Majesty from and against any and all kinds of claims or liens accruing from labour and services performed and material furnished or otherwise, and any of the same in or about the works.

21. PATENT CLAIMS AND ROYALTIES

(a) His Majesty shall indemnify the Contractor against all actions, claims or proceedings for infringement of any patent or industrial design rights or of any alleged patent or industrial design rights (hereinafter referred to as "patent rights") in carrying out his contract, and for royalties or other payments which may be payable in connection with any such patent rights (including any amounts properly payable by the Contractor to any of its sub-contractors pursuant to any similar covenant of indemnity given by the Contractor to any sub-contractor), in respect of anything the model, plan or design of which shall have been provided by or on behalf of His Majesty, but this indemnity shall apply to this contract only.

(b) Save and except as set forth in sub-section (a) of this section, the Contractor shall indemnify His Majesty against all actions, claims or proceedings for infringement of any patent rights and for royalties or other payments which may be payable in connection with any such patent rights in carrying out this contract.
(c) Before making any payments with respect to any patent rights, the Contractor shall supply to the Minister a statement showing all payments and claims for payment by way of royalties or otherwise which the Contractor or any of its sub-contractors will or may be obligated to make or proposes to make to the owner or holder of any patent rights in connection with this contract, and the basis thereof and the parties to whom the same are payable, and shall from time to time promptly advise the Minister of any and all claims or arrangements made or proposed, which would or might result in further or different payment being made by the Contractor or any of its sub-contractors by way of royalties or otherwise as aforesaid.

(d) If and when the Minister shall so direct, the Contractor shall make no payment by way of royalties or otherwise with respect to any patent rights referred to in any statement furnished by the Contractor as provided in sub-section (c) of this section, except with the consent of the Minister and subject to such conditions as the Minister may impose and from and after the giving of any such direction by the Minister, His Majesty shall indemnify the Contractor against any action, claim or proceeding for infringement of the patent rights covered by such direction or for non-payment of royalties or other payments in respect thereof.

22. SANITATION

The Contractor shall comply with, and the work shall be carried on subject to all regulations made by any lawful authority and applicable to said work, and all orders given by the Indian Agent with respect to sanitation or preservation of health on the work. The Contractor shall make adequate arrangements, to the satisfaction of the Indian Agent, for the medical and sanitary supervision of all his employees.

23. INDIAN AGENT'S MARKS

The Contractor shall protect, and shall not remove or destroy, or permit to be removed or destroyed, the stakes, buoys and other marks placed on or about the said work by the Indian Agent or his assistants, and shall furnish the necessary assistance to correct or replace any stake, buoy or mark which through any cause may have been removed or destroyed.

24. NOTICES

Any notice, order, direction or other communication given to the Contractor under any of the provisions of this contract shall be sufficiently given if delivered to the Contractor personally, or to his foreman, or left at the Contractor's office, or mailed at any post office to the Contractor or foreman addressed to the address mentioned in the contract, or to the Contractor's last known place of business or residence.

25. PROGRESS MEASUREMENTS AND CERTIFICATES NOT BINDING

The progress measurements and progress certificates shall not in any respect be taken as binding upon the Indian Agent or as final measurements or as fixing final amounts; they are to be subject to the revision of the Indian Agent in making up his final certificate, and they shall not in any respect be taken as an acceptance of the work or as a release of the Contractor from responsibility in respect thereof.
26. PROTECTION OF WORK

The Contract and all information issued in connection therewith are confidential and their use must be strictly confined to the work and to the purpose of the contract; and particulars contained therein; and other matter issued in connection therewith, must not be disclosed to unauthorized persons.

The Contractor shall at all times take and cause to be taken all reasonable measures, for the protection of the work against espionage and sabotage, and on the order of the Minister shall dispense with the services of any person employed in, about or upon the work or cause the same to be dispensed with. The Minister shall at all times through such agency as he may see fit be entitled to maintain, near or about the premises where the work or any part thereof is being carried on such police or other protective force as in the opinion of the Minister may be advisable.

27. CANADIAN WORK AND MATERIALS

To the full extent that the same are procurable, only Canadian labour, parts and materials (unless otherwise agreed by the Minister) shall be used in connection with the work.

27a. EMPLOYMENT OF EX-SERVICE MEN

In engaging labour for the work contemplated by this contract, either from the National Employment Service or from Trade Unions with which the contractor has collective agreements, the contractor shall specify that preference shall be given to competent and available ex-service men.

The contractor shall maintain and keep available for inspection by the Minister a record of the names and addresses of ex-service men employed, together with a record of the steps taken to implement this requirement.

28. SALARIES

The salaries payable to engineers, superintendents, draftsmen and foremen shall only be such as shall be approved by the Minister.

29. TERMINATION

(a) Notwithstanding anything in this contract contained the Minister may, by giving notice to the Contractor, terminate the contract (save and except the provisions of this section and of Section 14 of these general conditions) as regards all or any part or parts of the work or works not theretofore completed. Upon such notice being given, the Contractor shall cease work (including the procuring of materials for the fulfilment of the contract) in accordance with and to the extent specified in such notice but shall proceed with all reasonable speed to complete such part or parts (if any) of the work or works as are by the terms of such notice to be completed and shall also proceed with all reasonable speed to complete up to such time and/or stage as may be specified in the notice any part or parts of the work or works as required by such notice. The Minister may, at any time, or from time to time, give one or more additional notices with respect to any or all parts of the work which remain to be completed after the giving of any previous notice or notices.

(b) All work completed by the Contractor under or pursuant to the provisions of the contract before or after the giving of any notice, subject to acceptance by His Majesty in accordance with the provisions of the contract, shall be paid for on the basis provided in the agreement (the Contractor being allowed such fraction of his
stipulated fee as shall be proportionate to the amount of the work theretofore completed) and the Contractor shall be entitled to be reimbursed the actual cost to the contractor of work not completed under or pursuant to the provisions of this contract and/or any notice given pursuant thereto plus a fair and reasonable premium in respect of work done thereunder provided that no reimbursement shall be made for materials which have been or may be rejected after inspection as not complying with the terms and conditions of this contract and the specifications.

(c) In the event that the Contractor and the Minister are unable to agree upon the amount in respect of which the Contractor is entitled to be reimbursed as aforesaid, the matter shall be referred to the Exchequer Court.

(d) Whenever practicable the Contractor shall procure materials required for the performance of the contract on terms that will enable it to terminate any contracts entered into by the Contractor upon completion of the terms similar in effect to those herein provided for in respect to the termination the Minister and the giving of a notice or notices as aforesaid; and generally the Contractor shall co-operate with His Majesty and the Minister and do everything reasonably within its power at all times to minimize and reduce the amount of His Majesty's obligations under the provisions of this section.

(e) Upon reimbursement being made to the Contractor as herein provided, title to the materials and/or work in progress in respect of which such reimbursement is made shall pass to and vest in His Majesty (the Contractor hereby agreeing to execute and deliver all requisite instruments by way of further assurance) and the materials and/or work in progress shall be delivered to the order of the Minister, but the materials thus taken over will in no case be in excess of what would have been required for performing the contract in full if no notice had been given under the provisions hereof.

(f) If it is established to the satisfaction of the Minister by the Contractor that by reason of any action taken by the Minister under the provisions of this section exceptional hardship has resulted to the Contractor then the Minister may notwithstanding any other provisions of this section, in his absolute discretion grant such allowance (not to include in any case however, any allowance or compensation for loss of profit) to the Contractor as, in the opinion of the Minister is warranted by the circumstances.

(g) Any action, decision or determination by the Minister under the provisions of this section shall be final and binding upon the Contractor.

(h) The Contractor shall have no claim for damages, compensation loss of profits, allowance or otherwise by reason of or directly or indirectly arising out of any action taken or notice given by the Minister under or pursuant to the provisions of this section except as and to the extent in this section expressly provided.

(i) The right of termination and of giving notice hereinbefore provided shall be in addition to and not in substitution for any other right possessed by His Majesty and/or the Minister.

30. LABOUR CONDITIONS

The Contractor shall comply with and be subject to all the terms and conditions of the Labour Conditions (if any) referred to in the agreement and to all variations and modifications thereof that may at any time be enacted or brought into force during the continuance of the contract.

February 8th, 1949.

With further reference to my letter of December 27th in acknowledgment of Mr. Pratt's letter of December 8th relative to our obtaining a Contract from G.M. Adomeit and Company, Smithers, B.C., covering the erection of the office and medical quarters at Hazelton. This work is progressing favourably and on January 29th we forwarded to Adomeit and Company a copy of the necessary Contract for signature and it is being assumed that the signed Contract will be in our hands within a few days.

To comply with the terms of the Contract, particularly under Schedule A "Definition of Work" you will note that Sections (j), (k) and (m) indicate that it is necessary that the approval of the Minister be obtained for certain expenditures. These expenditures cover the hiring of such items as power driven machinery not actually owned by the Contractor and involves the hiring of a bulldozer for one or two days at a per diem cost of $75.00, the hiring of a power saw for a few days at a very moderate rental, as well as the limited rental of a truck at approximately $3.00 per hour. These expenditures would also include the cost involved in housing and feeding of workers as well as the proportionate cost of the salaries of Adomeit's accountant and himself and such other items as our Treasury officials consider come within sections (j), (k) and (m) of Schedule A of this Contract.

In order to expedite this work could approval be obtained, please, to have these authorities signed by myself as representing the Minister for purposes of the Contract and to
comply with Treasury audit requirements. This entire expenditure should not involve an amount in excess of $1000.

A similar approval appears essential to cover the recent Contract with R.C. Gooderich, 226 Wellington Avenue, Chilliwack, B.C., for the labour in erecting a two classroom school and attached teacher's residence at Pemberton, B.C., which Contract involves an amount estimated not to exceed $4600, of which amount only a few hundred dollars would come within the suggested approval.

I trust that these approvals may be obtained in order to facilitate the completion of these Contracts and the payment of the contract prices when satisfactorily completed without undue delay.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

With reference to your recent letter I enclose Applications No. 1 and 2 required in connection with the cost audit of the expenditure incurred in the erection of the Pemberton Indian Day School.

We have just received your Vouchers Nos. 328, 329, 330, 346 and 347, and payment of them will be made. If there are any accounts in connection with this school that can be forwarded in the near future, I would appreciate it if you would do so, as we are endeavouring to pay as many accounts as possible from the appropriation for the fiscal year 1948-49. The time is rapidly approaching when this procedure will be stopped, and all expenditures will have to be paid from the appropriation for the fiscal year 1949-50.

I feel certain that you will co-operate with us in every possible manner, both with regard to this school and other schools, in order that accounts dated not later than March 1st may reach us at the earliest possible date so that payment can be made from the 1948-49 appropriation.

Superintendent Gillett and Mr. R.C. Goodrich called here yesterday and we discussed with them the work necessary for completion of the above-mentioned school building. This work is detailed in the attached memorandum from Mr. Gillett and you will note that the estimated cost is $2700.00 for labour and $357.00 for materials, a total of $3057.00, in addition to which we have yet to pay from this year's appropriation for the lighting plant purchased from the Northern Electric Company, Limited, at a cost of $1758.25 and for the plumbing and heating installations which could not be completed prior to March 31st, at a cost of $472.00. It is apparent, therefore, that allowing for contingencies, we should arrange for the transfer of $7500.00 for completion of this building and I would recommend that this amount be transferred from the balance of funds appropriated for erection of the classroom block at Alberni.

With regard to carrying out of the work, Mr. Goodrich is prepared to complete the work under the same financial arrangement as was entered into for the erection of the building, that is, cost plus 10%, but it occurs to me that the Department may not be able to enter into such a contract this year, without first investigating the possibilities of securing firm tenders. Personally, I feel that we can have the building completed by Mr. Goodrich on a cost plus basis for less than a contract price.

Will you please advise at the earliest possible date how you would like completion of this building handled and in the interval I should like to have authority for the expenditure
necessary for the clearing of brush from the school site as it is essential that this burning be carried out before the hot weather in early June causes a serious fire hazard. Mr. Goodrich estimates the cost of burning the brush at $480.00 but Mr. Gillett is of the opinion that we can have it done with Indian labour for less.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
NEW SCHOOL AT PEMBERTON.

Attached is a list giving the estimated work to complete the School.

The building leaks, apparently in one of the valleys. It could be a case of having the shingles nailed too close to the valley, and thus have nail holes through the sheet iron.

The main entrance steps and platform will have to be reconstructed because the ground level is eighteen inches above the basement windows. The posts which support the rail on the sides of the platform should go to the ground as a matter of safety.

The cement floor is rough and not properly hardened. A layer of one inch of a finer mixture is required to make a smooth surface.

I believe there should be facings on the inside of the basement windows the full thickness of the cement wall to give a neater appearance.

Levelling the School grounds will require a bulldozer to push the gravel which was excavated for the basement to the cement walls and fill low spots. The ground level around the school will have to be lowered from 12 to 18 inches.

The two large piles of brush on the grounds should be burned. Some bulldozing is also necessary in connection with a road to the School.

ESTIMATE OF WORK TO COMPLETE NEW SCHOOL AT HEMBERTON.

1. Reconstructing platform and steps. Placing concrete blocks for steps and posts to rest on.

   Requirements - 2 bags cement - 65 man hours.

2. Platform and steps to Teacher's entrance.

   Requirements - 2 bags cement - 40 man hours.

3. Door into basement. Concrete wall has to be knocked out to make room for a door. The entrance to the doorway will be lower than the ground level. This will necessitate some excavating and concrete.

   Requirements - 10 bags cement, door 3' x 6' and frame 9½" wide - 100 man hours.

4. Roof - to be fixed where leaks have developed. Eavetroughs should be tarred on inside.

   Requirements - 20 man hours.

5. Basement floor. Needs another layer of 1" thick cement, of one part cement and two parts sand.

   Requirements - 82 bags cement, 6 yards sand - 140 man hours.

   Sand will cost approximately $2.00 per yard delivered.

6. Basement windows. 12 panes of glass to be renewed. Windows will have to be taken out to be repaired. To make a better job I consider it necessary to have the facing on the inside.

   Requirements - 25 man hours.

7. Grounds. The ground level around the School will have to be taken down 18" due to the fact that the windows in the basement are 18" below the ground level. Brush, logs and stumps to be piled and burned.

8. Bathroom. Some finishing work to be done in bathroom after plumbing fixtures installed. Difficult to estimate.

9. Floors to be sanded. This can be done after the electrical equipment is installed. Placing of the kitchen sink and drainboard to be faced with masonite. Trimming to be put around edge of sink. Holes to be cut for cold and hot air vents.

10. Outhouses - Holes to be dug and cribbed and outhouses to be set in place on top of holes. Doors to be made and hung on outhouses. Locks to be put on doors.

   Requirements - 20 man hours.

11. Painting - Paint job three coats outside, two coats inside.

Re: Pemberton Indian Day School
Your File 865-5 (E.1)

With reference to Mr. Phelan's letter of May 27th, we are of the opinion that Mr. Goodrich performed his work in connection with the erection of the above mentioned school in a quite satisfactory manner, considering the time of year during which construction was carried out and the most unusual winter conditions which prevailed last year. I think we could conservatively estimate that construction costs were increased at least twenty-five percent by reason of our inability to authorize the commencement of construction at an earlier date.

With regard to the following to which particular reference is made in Mr. Phelan's letter, I would advise:

(1) The roof leaks are in the valley of the roof where the flashing is nailed too close to the centre. This can be very easily repaired.

(2) Reconstructing platform and steps - Due to winter weather conditions it was not possible to back fill and permanent steps and platform could not be constructed until the back fill was done.

(3) Door into basement - The plan of the building did not show a basement door. Mr. Goodrich carried out instructions in accordance with the plan. This was an omission on our part - we should have had the plan changed.
(4) Failure of the basement floor to properly harden was due to weather conditions. This can be remedied by laying a finish coat of sand and cement.

I have requested Superintendent Gillett to arrange for completion of the building on a day labour basis and to requisition for the materials required. I should appreciate being advised when the funds required are transferred and if it will be in order for us to have the work proceeded with.

W.S. Arneil,

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Pemberton Indian Day School,
New Westminster Indian Agency,
Province of British Columbia,
Electoral District of Cariboo.

The construction of the above school was commenced during the fiscal year 1948-49. In order to complete it, Indian Commissioner Arneil states that the following work is required at a cost of approximately $2,700.00:

Finishing basement and toilets.
Painting interior and exterior.
Levelling lot.
Excavating for septic tank.
Digging well and cribbing same.

Re: Electric Light - Pemberton School

The electric lighting plant purchased for the new school at Pemberton is of sufficient size to provide electricity to the old classroom and teacherage and we have for consideration from Superintendent Gillett an estimate of the cost of carrying power to the old school and wiring the building, a total of $234.16.

District School Inspector Davey informs me that, during a recent visit to Pemberton, he noted that even without artificial light, the old classroom, due to the smaller window space, was much darker than the new classrooms, in fact, even at mid-day it was too dark for the pupils to carry on their studies efficiently. The need for artificial light is therefore greater in the old school than in the new school and it is felt that we should endeavour to make the necessary funds available for wiring the building.

I might mention we have been unofficially advised that the B.C. Electric Company will have power available in the vicinity of the school, possibly next year, but there would appear to be no reason to wait until then as we have ample power available.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Re: Old Pemberton School Building

With reference to Superintendent Gillett's letter of October 22nd and enclosure attached, the heating system in the above-mentioned building is not functioning satisfactorily, for the reason that there is no direct cold air return from the classroom to the furnace. This results in increased fuel consumption, inefficient heating and a poor circulation of air.

Installation of the cold air return will cost $162.50 and I would recommend that an expenditure of this amount be approved.

W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Re: The Pemberton One Room School

The cold air circuit in the building was not constructed to give efficient results. It does not take the cold air off the floor of the school room. In fact, any dust or smoke in the basement will rise to the school room from the cold air vents.

The pipes from the two cold air grills go down the walls within two feet of the basement floor. The open grill on the bottom of the furnace is expected to draw the air to the furnace. This does not happen, however.

To have the heat properly distributed through the school and teacher's quarters it will be necessary to have improvements made as outlined in the attached copy of a letter from Mitchell Brothers Ltd.

I recommend that this be authorized.

J. Gillett,
Agency Supt.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6421, file 865-11, part 1)
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

I have received a request from Miss Mary McDonald, teacher at the Pemberton Indian Day School, to be supplied with the following material for her classes:

**SEWING & KNITTING.**

- 4 yards towelling,
- 1 package, assorted needles,
- 2 spools white thread,
- 4 yards cotton print,
- 2 packages bias tape,
- 6 pairs knitting needles,
- 6 sets knitting needles,
- 2 lbs. knitting wool.

**MANUAL TRAINING.**

- 1 Back Saw.
- 1 ½ chisel,
- 1 Compass Saw.
- 1 Hammer.
- 1 Screw Driver.

She would also like to start a daily tooth-brush drill, and asks for some 4 dozen tooth-brushes and a supply of camphorated chalk.

The cost of the Sewing and Manual training supplies will be less than $20.00, and I would recommend authority be given. The tooth-brushes could probably be ordered through the Department of Pensions and National Health.

I may say that Miss McDonald is very pleased with both the school and pupils, which she says is one of the nicest she has ever seen.

A.O.M. Daunt, Indian Agent.
Ottawa, September 27, 1943.

Mr. A.O.N. Daunt, Indian Agent, New Westminster, B.C.

With reference to your letter of the 21st instant, you may purchase the sewing and manual training supplies requested by the Pemberton Indian Day School. It is noted that there cost will be approximately $20.00.

Forty-eight toothbrushes and a supply of camphorated chalk will be sent to the teacher from this office.

Philip Phelan,

STIKINE INDIAN AGENCY REPORT FOR MONTH OF MARCH 1936

Father Bosse' came as far as Caribou Hide with the party, and we practically settle a site for next winters Nomadic School.

Some of these families have 10 - 12 and 13 children to take around, and it is almost impossible for them to get out, with their families to the far distant trap grounds. Therefore for a few years to come, as in the past, they settle on some good spot, and create a large Winter Camp. It is at these places that a Mission School should be created, not necessary every year in the same location.

In this way, with a capable teacher to watch over the Camp generally, and carry on a school for the children, the men folk will be able to get out, and moreover stay out, bringing back returns.

However with the arrival of Inspector Pragnell, all the Indians concerned will be seen, and some definite action settled.

Harper Reed
Indian Agent.
Sir,

The matter of schooling for the Caribou Hide Band of Indians was taken up with Inspector Pragnell upon his visit here. He instructed that a requisition should be submitted, for aid, along the lines that Father Bonse' O.M.I., and your Agent thought best on their visit to these Indians last winter, and reported in the usual Monthly Diary. It is as follows.

Jim Moyess has given his "hun" for a School house. Desks and seats are made out of their own cut lumber. The school will receive about 15 Youngsters (all R.C.'s). The Cripple Jimmy, a member of their Band should act as School-teacher until the R.C. Mission can see their way clear to send a schoolmaster in for the winter months. That Cripple Jimmy should be allowed a set sum per month, and he will not then receive "ations as he has been used to. The salary it is considered should be $20.00 per month—period for 6 months. As provisions are very dear in price this seems the least that can be allowed.

School material of simple form must be provided and sent in from Tadla Lake B.C. by the Two Brothers Mining Co.'s Plane which can ground on Netspan Lake, upon which is the Indian Camp.

All schooling matters to be under their Head-Man - Jim Moyess. Also 1 Doz sheets of Glass if supplied would give the extra light required in the already constructed School-house.

Father Bonse' O.M.I. on his next visit would check up all operations.

The above is considered to be the very best, and least expensive, way of supplying the Band with schooling—pro temp.

The Secretary,
The Dept. Indian Affairs.
OTTAWA.

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Harper Reed,
Indian Agent.

I beg to submit hereunder, the Agency's Annual Report, covering the past year, ending on the 31st March 1936.

EDUCATION.

Small Winter Schools for trapping Nomads have received much attention during the year. It seems to be the only way, up to now whereby these youngsters can learn anything at all; it also helps to break down their wild nomadic ways. Two such places are really required. One for the Klappan Band of Indians and the other for the Caribou Hide Band.

The first Bands requirements have been gone into, and has now, after much trouble been reduced to supplying a teacher with school material, at their Big Camp on Kluechon Lake, all under the R. C. Mission of these parts. Father Bosse' O. M. I., in charge of such Missions here has written His Lordship, Bishop Bunoz, and requested him to supply a teacher. For such long winters work, and in so remote a place, a salary a little above the ordinary is expected. Upon the matter being investigated by Inspector Pragnell, shortly, a full and detailed report will be submitted to the Department.

The second Band - Caribou Hide. This Band is very remote, and the only possible action to take, is to supply the Chief - Jim Moyess, with full material, and he will instruct Cripple Jimmy, a very intelligent member of his band, to act as a teacher and supervise his work. In this event the teacher would be supplied with a monthly ration, with a very small salary for his services. Supplies for this Band would have to be sent to them, by the freighting planes of the Two Bros. Mining Company, who are operating within ten miles of the Indian camp. This also will have further attention.

Dear Sir,

in accordance with instructions received from your office dated October eighth I left Telegraph Creek in company with a pack train which was travelling as far as the Klappan Indian school. Upon arrival at the settlement I there met some Indians about to leave for their traplines on the Spatzier river. These men kindly undertook to guide myself as far as the crossing of the caribou Hyde trail roughly four miles below Hylands Poston the Spatzier river.

Having placed me on this trail these men left me and I followed this trail a distance of forty six miles to Carribou Hyde settlement arriving there at the end of October. Nearly all the men of the camp had left for their traplines, however all their children were at the camp. The chief gave the teacher permission to use his house as a school.

The school supplies which you had forwarded were in the chief's house and were in good condition. November first being a holiday of obligation a day in which we had no school.

All the children were keen to go to school and I found that they are self taught in the elementary work of schooling. One girl has taught herself to read the first books of the Canadian and Highroads readers. In regards to figures every child could count but had no idea of the written numbers above the number nine. Likewise in writing, their work was of a very childlike scrawl, since opening school I have found a great improvement in all branches of their work.

At present there are eleven children of school age and quite a few below school age who will be ready for school in the future.

Owing to the fact that I was late in getting here and as all the men of the camp had left for their trap lines and did not return until Christmas Eve we have up to the present only been able to get the logs for the future school building cut, after the men return from their pending trip to Telegraph Creek and the weather is suitable the building will be completed.
Nails and glass are absolutely nonexistent in this camp, but the chief informed that there was quite a number of nails and windows on the property of the Northern Gold Syndicate's property situated at McLaren Creek; he believed these could be purchased from this company. To ascertain if this was possible I went in company of the chief to this property and interviewed the watchman there.

My findings there was that there are considerable of part keys of nails and a number of windows about twelve and the watchman said he believed these could be purchased by applying to Mr O'Connell President
200 Lancaster Building
Calgary Alta.

Or
Mr Faulkson Manager
10 Broadway
Tacoma Wash.

These men could be contacted by wire from Telegraph Creek and if nails and glass could be purchased there it would be easier to haul them the seventeen miles from that camp than from Telegraph Creek.

To cover the roof with tar paper it will require (1350) thirteen hundred and fifty square feet of paper this will be sufficient to cover both the school building and the teachers quarters.

Having walked the whole way from Telegraph Creek to here I am of the opinion that it is economically impossible to ship school supplies to this place from that point to Caribou Hyde, as we have to consider the freight from Vancouver to Wrangell plus the cost up the Stikine river to Telegraph creek after that these supplies would have to be hauled by pack train or dog team a distance of two hundred and fifty miles to this point, the cost of that being (40¢) forty cents per pound or ($800) eight hundred dollars per ton. Sir,

I beg to submit hereunder a Report on the new venture of a Bush-Day-School (Winter) for the Caribou Hide of Indians. Submitted herewith is the School Report as far as it has gone, and Mr Anglin, the school Teacher has been instructed to make same out monthly, for the future. Also is a rough out-line of work done and efforts intended for the future, made out by Mr Anglin; who is much better at his rough work, than making out a report on same.

The Department will no doubt remember that this excellent Band of Nomads are situated 250 miles to the south east of this Town, but have consistently demanded to be taught things. Supplies have been sent out and with these much good ground work was accomplished by their self elected teacher - Cripple Jimmy. It was thought that another school such as the Klappan Affair could be started here, with it is hoped the same good results. More Indian families are expected up from Bear Lake way and taken in all this band should increase in the very near future. Also it might be mentioned, as far as can be ascertained to-day the proposed Alaskan highway, or rather the Pacific Highway, is due to pass right through, or very near, this Bands front door step.

Acting on an Authority from The Department received by Wire, Mr Anglin walked out to this spot last Fall. His trip was very hard, and altho there was no trail in places, the time he made in arriving there was indeed good.

He is most keen to go ahead with this work, and as a start it would be hard to find a more suitable man. His data is not quite correct as to freight rates, so attached is submitted a copy of a letter on this matter received from the H.B.C., which your Agent agrees with entirely.

Dear Sir,

After a long walk and much trouble I have just survived the trip through from Caribou Hyde to this place. As I stated when last I saw you I ordered a plane to come to Caribou Hyde to get me and told the pilot that I would wait until the Fifth of June but no longer; on the fifth I realized that my wait had been in vain. A telegraph told me that there was a radio transmitter at Fort Ware so I walked there in the hopes of getting a plane to bring me through but on arrival I found that the transmitter had been shipped out for repairs and as there was no hopes of getting a message out or a plane in.

Having promised the Bishop that I would come here I highered a guide and walked through from Fort Ware to McDames, the man that I highered had not been over the trail before but I could not have got a better man anywhere and we made the trip through in thirteen days. We had to build no less than five rafts on that trip besides crossing innumerable creeks every one in flood and on the whole trip I was wet through every day but I saw some wonderful country.

Before leaving Caribou Hyde I had made out the required materials for the school building, but those papers were spoilt in my pack sack, through having to cross the above mentioned Creeks and Rivers and I find that I have to make them all out again.

The first estimate of a building was impracticable as I found on looking the logs over which had been cut that there was not timber in that place big enough to construct a school thirty feet long and the longest log which had been cut was twenty two (22) ft so I told them to make the school square twenty by twenty (20) it is proposed to put a half pitch on the roof, and as near as I can ascertain the required amount of roofing paper is nine hundred fifty (950) sq ft. This will be sufficient to cover both the school and the teacher's quarters.

Windows required are six (four for the school and two for the teacher's quarters). Doors three. Nails of different sizes about two hundred (200) lbs.

During the past winter I was highly satisfied with the progress the children of Caribou Hyde made in the school work, every child there from the smallest to the biggest is keen to learn.

My salary received to date amounted to seven hun-
Dred ninety (790$) of which I paid out for food and transportation almost seven hundred (700$). This I think is a little steep for one teacher to have to bear. As I stated on the letter I forwarded to you in January of this year the only feasible method of getting things into this place is by air, and if the bishop wishes me to return to Caribou Hyde this winter that is how I intend to get the winter's supplies of food for myself and also myself in to that place. But to buy the supplies and pay for the plane myself will still be a steep proposition and I think I should receive some assistance from the department. I am quite willing to pay half of the charter of the plane.

In accordance with instructions from your office whilst residing at Caribou Hyde I went to the trap line of Chief Jim Moyez and there staked a quarter section of land the same to be set aside as an Indian reserve, this was done early in December of 1938, but I mislaid the papers of the staking and it meant making a return trip so during the Easter holiday I took one man and went and visited that place again, changing the dates on the post to the nineteenth (19) of April 1939. I enclose a copy of the notice which I left affixed to the corner posts on the afore said land.

Hoping the above meets with your approval and hoping to meet you again at some future date

I beg to remain
yours sincerely
JAE Anglin

Dear Sir,

In re your enquiries as to the school house at this point as you know the chief in the XXXXX name of his band promised that if a teacher was sent to this place these Indians would build a school house and living quarters for the teacher.

During the winter 1938-9 whilst here I endeavoured to cut the logs of the building and was told that the Indians would skin them to the site during the summer and put the walls up leaving the finishing to be done upon my return to open school for the following winter.

When I returned here I found that nothing whatever had been done to bring either to skid these logs or make fresh ones. One man only attempted to give me any assistance in constructing this place the size of which is 22ft by 20ft. Height of walls being 8ft6ins plus a gable of quarter pitch the roof is of poles ripped in half with whip saw and scoop on the top of that again, the length of the poles and scoop are 14ft6ins to allow an over lap of 1ft6ins.

For flooring poles again were used and ripped in half, their length being 11ft.

The teachers quarters are in the shape of a lean-to at the back of the school house size 16ft by 13ft this is also constructed with pole and scoop roof.

Now as I said only one man volunteered to help me and for the amount of work to be done it would have meant that we two would have been working all winter at it but I came to teach a school and so I endeavoured to use the money which is paid to me as salary to get this place finished having paid out the following amounts for ripping and skidding these logs etc by dog teams a distance of over half a mile.

Rob Abesta Quack $50.00
Joseph Leon Dennis $203.00
Antoine Hunter $25.00
Peter Lee Dennis $20.00
Walter Leon Dennis $18.00
Antoine Louis $10.00

Wages $196.00
Nails and glass $20.00
Total $216.00

This is the total amount which I have paid out in order to build this school house as far as I have been able to go.

According to the plan which I drew up I allowed for five windows in the school house and two in the living quarters, but so far I was unable to obtain the glass for such a number and so I have two only in the school house and one only in the teachers quarters. For heating...
the school house I had to borrow a large stove from one of the Indians which came I have have to return at the end of the school term. For the teacher's quarters I have to do the best I can on an old tin stove which is too small. Hence it will require two (2) stoves for this place if this school is to run next winter.

Before leaving in the spring I intend to thoroughly chink this new place with moss and leave it ready for instant reposing in the fall leaving here some time in June for Telegraph Creek. Until I see you, believe me to remain

Yours very sincerely

AGENT'S REPORT ON STIKINE AGENCY FOR MONTH OF APRIL

The R.C.Mission Seasonal schools are nominally under the supervision of the Rev. Father Carpentier, O.M.I., and during the winter three such schools have been in operation viz. Klappen Day School - Dease Lake School, and that of Caribou Hide. Reports on all the above have been rendered to the Department whenever it was possible to do so. As this month sees the breaking of winter into the summer season, it is mentioned that three summer season schools will be in operation this year, viz., Thalton Reserve Anglican, as mentioned above. I beg to submit a Report on the non-operations of the above Winter Seasonal School.

Under Authority 156-8-1, July 17th 1940 permission was granted to operate the above school during this winter for a period of Four Months. The Salary allowed was at the rate of $110.00, arranged at this advanced rate on account of the inaccessibility of the school's location. The Teacher was to have been nominated at a later date. School supplies were granted and received at this point, and now await forwarding. Also some extras were allowed such as Fuel for light etc.

Much correspondence has passed on the affairs of this Bush School, perhaps for which its very remoteness is responsible. It will be remembered that Mr Anglin was the Teacher in charge during the winter of 1939-1940, and that owing to some general disorders, a new Teacher was requested. During the summer many attempts were made to definite secure the name of the proposed Teacher from His Lordship Bishop Bunoz, O.M.I., but up to the time of writing; all efforts have failed, and therefore the school has, as yet, not been opened up.

The location of this school is about 250 miles away from any trading post. This makes travel to such a point a matter for the use of the old Dog-team transportation, not only to arrive at such a point but to also keep oneself in meat etc and be able to move about, if necessary. It calls for an "outside man of experience who is also a "teacher" and will take an unselfish interest in the Indians as a whole - such men are hard to find. His Lordship Bishop Bunoz certainly expects that the Department should send the school supplies in by Air, and at the same time allow the Teacher a free passage. This request was advanced to the Department but under a letter -156-8-1, it was decided that during the War period, and the heavy expenses now being born by the Department, it was impossible to comply with the Bishop's request.

In a letter recently received from Father Carpentier O.M.I. who is in charge of the Mission's affairs in these parts; and at present at Dease Lake with Father Plain as his assistant, it states that he will be coming into Telegraph Creek around about Xmas time, and then the matter of sending Father Plain out to Caribou Hide will be gone into.
