When I reached Carbon Hitle on 15th of February, in the school house, it was as cold as in a camp fire. Indeed the wind was coming from everywhere in the room, even the light was flashing through the walls, may be to help the little windows which do not give enough light inside. The people helped me to think, but it is not easy to keep warm in winter with an old heater kept by an Indian.

To put on fact the school, I think we need roofing paper; the school is 22 ft. by 20 ft each side of the roof is 22 ft. by 14 ft. The kitchen is 14 ft. by 11 ft. with a flat roof. To warm the room we need a big heater with 12 inches pipe in the school and a little stove with 8-6 inches pipe in the kitchen. To light the room we need 2 more big windows for the school, 2 little windows for the little shop - a gas lamp, a coil oil lamp. An assortment of nails 10 pounds about.

Rev. John J. Harris
The Department might bring to mind that when this school was originally started, that the Two Brothers Mining Company of Edmonton Alta., commenced mining operations at Two Brothers Lake - some 8 miles to the east of the Caribou Hide Village, and that whilst the mining company were in operation our Indians lived in very good style. However for the last 4 or 5 years the mining operations have ceased, and it would seem that the equipment that is left on their site, is really abandoned. The Indians report that there are a lot of good windows, not uncased, good supply of nails. Many empty Gas Drums. 3 Big Tents (6 stripe) hung up in the old buildings. Some cross cut saws, and a quantity of mattresses, although somewhat by mice, could still be sewn up and made use of. Also they report much crockery, and many odd tools. Whilst the old lumber buildings now falling down, could be used to great advantage, if they could be obtained. It is stated on behalf of our Indians that they have no power will not touch such property until the correct authority is obtained.

However, were this possible, it would settle the whole matter in regards to the living conditions of this Band of Indians, and also place their school in very good shape.

Therefore The Deputy Minister of Mines, for the Province of B.C. in Victoria B.C., is being respectfully written to, requesting to know as to the standing of the Two Brothers Mining Coy, and as to if this old property, with its equipment has been placed - up for sale.

Re:- Caribou Hide. Winter-school. AFFAIRS.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter dated April 26th, 1941, and with the arrival back to here of Teacher Rev Father Plain C.M.I., after closing down this winter school; it is possible to report further details. Submitted herewith is a letter from the Rev Father, whilst his School Reports have been rendered under separate cover, in this mail.

To bring matters up to date it is mentioned that the Department have been kind enough to allow the following:
The yearly School teaching supplies, which have now arrived here, and will await the means of sending them to that far distant location.
Under Authority 158-8-5. April 29th 1941 the sum of $36-50 has been granted to purchase a Lamp and various other school building necessities - which are now being obtained; with also an allowance of $20-00 to create a suitable Heater for the School itself. This also is being made up from an Oil Drum etc.

Much correspondence has passed regarding this School, but with the return of Father Plain, backed by several of the Caribou Hide Indians; who came in to sell fur and obtain some provisions - it is now very evident that this school can be made into a worth-while project - if stood once and for all on its feet, and placed into shape as a going concern.

As the Department knows, the whole crux of this matter comes down to one of Transportation. It has been utterly impossible to have supplies sent out, so far away. The Indians that come in, have all they can do to move out the bare necessities of life, which comprise for them, some clothing - Tea & tobacco, with a little Flour and sugar. The Teacher, who-ever he is, simply exists on what he can take out on one sleigh, and has to live mostly on meat, as do all the others.

The Department's kind consideration is again enlisted on behalf of some assistance in the way of transportation and this is really necessary to have the school put in correct shape to operate. After it has once been placed so, then the Teacher can move out and in, by the trail and the little extra in supplies yearly can be taken out by Dog-teams.

To do this, either a Plane could be chartered, or Indians hired to make the trip by dog-team, but the latter could not transport a Heater or any very large equipment. The costs in both cases would nearly be equal, and run to $100-00 or slightly over.

The School House roof at present is made out of scolloped small timbers - not very good in cold weather. Roofing paper - Medium weight should be allowed to cover this building - it would be good for many years to come. The Rev Father speaks about some windows, and these also are a necessity. Up to now sheets of glass, set into the logs have done service.

AGENT'S REPORT ON STIKINE AGENCY FOR MONTH OF JUNE 1941.

On the 21st inst. Bishop Coudret O.M.I. of the R.C. Missions arrived for his yearly inspection of the Cassiar. All matters were again gone over with him, and the various Seasonal schools were taken in hand and teachers and supplies arranged for. Later these were reported upon, but it is doubtful just at present if it will be possible to have a teacher go out to the Caribou Hide school. However the Department have been good enough to allow the sum of One hundred dollars towards getting the much needed freight out to that point, and the matter is now receiving attention as to the possibility of engaging a plane for such work. During the interview, some mention was made that a lot of local children were living within the Township during the winter, and did not attend the local Provincial school, and that if the local R.C. Mission could start up a small winter school at this point, many children would certainly attend. It was at once pointed out that should this be entertained matters in the Township would certainly become worse than they are at present; and the object of our Bush Winter schools would be entirely nullified. Eventually His Lordship agreed that such was the case, and it is hoped the matter is settled again, for some time to come. Telegraph Creek is certainly no place for an indian winter school.

Stikine Agency.

According to Mr. Reed, this school was constructed by the Department in 1939 under the direction of the teacher J.A.J. Anglin, who on April 14th, 1940 according to the files made a claim of $195.00 paid out by him for Indian labour and $200.00 for material, a total of $395.00, without authorization, which was submitted to the Department on July 4th, 1940. The Department replying on July 17th, 1940 File 1687-6-1 that the claim could not be entertained for lack of funds. About this time Mr. Anglin enlisted, leaving behind him some unsettled accounts, it being suggested by Father Carpentier on July 14th, 1941 that the Department might entertain payment of the accounts and take over the school, regarding which no action was taken by the Agent. From this it would appear the Church consider that at least they have some claim on the building. I have requested Mr. Sampson to investigate the matter when he visits this outlying Band and report on the matter, with a suitable recommendation. It is presumed that any recommendation would not exceed the amount of Mr. Anglin's claim. I am not in favour of divided ownership of these schools and consider that any claims by the Church on the various schools in this agency should be carefully investigated and extinguished. The Agent should also secure signed resolutions by the various Bands transferring the land occupied, to the Department for the time the schools will be in operation.

No returns are available regarding attendance at this school and I am unable to make any comment on its continuation. Mr. Sampson will go into the matter carefully and will advise the Commissioner and the Department.

There are a quantity of supplies in Telegraph Creek to go out to the school. Transportation there is a serious and expensive problem, costing far more than the value of the material.

Dear Sir

I send you this present to advise you that I keep Father Plaine at Iskut Lake.

I hate to see Father going to Caribou Hide because beside the hardship of the trip and the living conditions especially touch in an unfinished house, there is a systematic opposition from the chief and a few boys who told me that they don't want Father there and that they would not cut wood for the School, etc.

Here, Father will be a good help for us, for we have to cut wood. I only got 2 cords from Jack Pete, that's all I can expect, and I am not going to spend any more money for wood. I rather like to see all the schools closing down.

If you ever get a chance to fly over to Caribou Hide, Father would go with you for missionary work, for except the chief and a few boys the rest of the band is the best people in the country.

Here enclosed a letter from Bishop giving confirmation of my appointment as Teacher at Iskut.

Yours truly,

"Carpentier, C.M.I."
Sir,

I beg to refer to Departmental letter dated September 5, 1941, in which authority to operate the Caribou Hide Seasonal Day School was granted.

Father Plaine, who was to teach at this school, now informs me that owing to the hardships of the trip in to Caribou Hide and while staying there, his senior priest, Father Carpentier, has persuaded him not to go in to Caribou Hide this winter. Copies of letters from the priests are herewith enclosed.

There are now only 3 children of school age at Caribou Hide and the attendance of two of the older boys would undoubtedly be poor as they go trapping with their fathers during the winter. Some families move away from Caribou Hide camp entirely when they go trapping and this also makes for poor attendance averages. It is also exceedingly uncertain that any person other than a Roman Catholic priest would be willing to teach at this isolated and distant spot. Under the circumstances I would respectfully suggest the school be kept closed for this winter at least.

The question of opposition to the teacher by the Indians, as reported by Father Carpentier, will be investigated when a visit is made to Caribou Hide.

Yours truly,

Extract from letter received from Bishop Coudert, dated September 23, 1942.

Cariboo Hide Winter Day School

The winter day school at Cariboo Hide could not be conducted last winter on account of the extreme difficulties of communication with that point and the lack of adequate accommodation. Father J. Plaine, O.M.I., one of our most zealous missionaries, was ready to undertake the task, but owing to inadequate means of transportation, I could not allow Father Plaine, who is not of a very robust health, to undertake again, as he did the previous year, at the peril of his life, a journey of 250 miles on foot in January, in order to reach his school. After the various attempts made during the past five years to conduct a day school at Cariboo Hide during the winter months, we came to the conclusion that no teacher will ever be found to go and teach at such a place unless proper housing accommodation is arranged by the Department and transportation is provided by airplane.

Extract from Report of Agent Iver Fougner, dated October, 1911 - Letter of November 3rd., 1911.

I also visited Ulkatcho Reserve.

They wanted some meadowland reserved; and wanted a day school for their children. These Indians are Roman Catholics, the number of children is 25.

(Sgd.) Iver Fougner,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, November 20, 1911.

Sir,

Replying to that portion of your letter of the 3rd instant in which you state that the Indians of the Ulkatcho Band want a day school and that there are 25 children I have to ask you to be good enough to submit a full report upon this request.

Your obedient servant,

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

Iver Pounger, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Bella Coola, B.C.
Sir:

Referring to your letter of 20 ultimo No. 399275/1, I have the honor to say that the Ulkatcho Indians have expressed a desire to get a school in their village. This village consists of small log-houses and is situated 150 north-east of Bella Coola, on the mountain plateau.

I visited the place in October; nearly all of the Indians, about 60 in number, were then away trapping. I then learned that there were 25 children, 14 boys and 11 girls under the age of 16.

It is my opinion that these Indians would take greater interest in a school than the coast Indians do; like the latter they are away from their village a great deal, however. They are devout Catholics and are visited once a year in the month of June by their priest, Father Thomas. I do not know how he feels toward the project.

The school-house ought to contain living-rooms for the teacher also. The houses must be built of logs which are plentiful in the vicinity; to build here would cost a little more than on the coast, as all the lumber needed will have to be sawed by hand labor.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Sec., Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, January 4, 1912.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 21st ultimo reporting further upon the request of the Ulkatcho Indians to have a school established in their village.

In reply I beg to say that it is noted that you state that you do not know how the Priest who administers to these Indians, Father Thomas, feels towards the project. Before going any further into the matter it is considered advisable that you should communicate with Father Thomas and obtain his views.

Your obedient servant,

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

Iver Fougner, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Hells Coola, B.C.

Sir,

I have the honour of answering your letter of January the 14th 1912, asking informations as to the project of an Indian school at Elgacho. My excuse for not answering sooner is that I have been away on a several months' holiday to Europe & just come back.

With regards to that project I think that it is useless to contemplate an industrial or boarding school at that above mentioned place on account of its situation, the nearest Indian reserve, Klastusy lake, being 60 miles away.

With regards to a day school, the two families able to fill the school live one 40 or 50 mile from Elgacho, at Abraham lake, the other 8 miles away. On a population of 50 souls nobody lives in the village during at least 6 months in the year, the people on account of their poor land & high altitude, having to be absent to make their living.

I sent a few weeks on my annual visit to those people & expect to be amongst them on the 8th of June.

These are the informations I have the honour...

To forward you without any intention of influencing the Dominion Government. Making excuses for not forwarding these informations sooner.

I remain,

Yours very sincerely,

August 18, 1919.

Dear Sir -

I have your letter of the 23rd ultimo, in reference to the establishment of a boarding school for the Indians of the Ulgatcho, Kluskus Lake and Ootca Lake Bands.

In reply to your enquiry as to whether this matter had ever previously considered, I would state that, as far back as 1911, the Indians of the Ulgatcho Lake Band asked for the establishment of a day school. It was thought well at that time to communicate with Rev. Father Thomas, their spiritual adviser, and in a letter dated April 27th, 1912, he stated that he considered it useless to contemplate an industrial or boarding school on account of the location of this reserve, and that a day school was not feasible. I have just returned from a trip to Ulgatcho and in connection therewith I beg to report as follows:-
I endeavour to visit this place every June arriving there at same time as the priest (Catholic missionary from Williams Lake, who visits Ulgatcho annually arriving there on or about June 10th).

They were told some years ago that an Agent would be stationed up there and that there would be a school for their children and medicine for them when they needed it.

There are approximately (according to their count) 75 children in the 3 places above mentioned, the nearest village (Ulgatcho) is 160 miles from Bella Coola and it is impossible to go in from here in the winter. Of course the trip could be made from here but it would mean quite an outlay for extra heavy clothing, snowshoes, etc.

The Indians feel however, that they should receive more attention and their children some training.

Quite a number of the men are starting to buy cattle this year and they already own large numbers of horses.

They say their children are like Coyotee and do not know any more, and the older people say they would like to see something done for their children before they (the old ones) die. Mr. Scott,

Sir:

Replying to your letter of 16th November, referring to the matter of the construction of an Indian day school on the Ulkatcho reserve, Bella Coola Agency, about which Mr. J. W. Hober, of Hagensborg, B. C., wrote you, I beg to say that from all information I have received on this question and taking into consideration the isolated location of the territory which the Ulkatcho Indians occupy and their nomadic habits convinces me that the establishment of a day school is utterly impracticable and I am of the opinion that the only sound method to pursue with regard to giving the Ulkatcho children an education is by having them placed in the new Industrial school at Fraser Lake as soon as it is opened, which will or should be some time next fall. This was mentioned in a memorandum dealing with the erection of residential schools in British Columbia which was sent to Mr. Scott on the 12th of October last, wherein I referred to the new school at Fraser Lake.

All correspondence I have had on this matter from late Constable Tucker and Mr. Indian Agent Fougeron go to show that what the Ulkatcho Indians really wanted was some sort of a boarding school in which to place their children while they and their wives were out trapping or hunting; and in a letter from Constable Tucker of 5th September, 1919, he stated that the Indians themselves said a day school would be useless. Agent Fougeron on 2nd September last also informed me that a day school would not be a success. It was at one time thought there were sufficient children in the Ulkatcho, Kluskus Lake and Ootsee Lake bands to warrant the establishment of a boarding school. The latter two bands are in the southern extremity of the Stuart Lake Agency. This was, however, before it was decided to build the new school at Fraser Lake.

The Ulkatcho village is over 120 miles from Bella Coola by trail. A large portion of the present reserve has been recommended to be cut off by the Royal Commission on account of it being considered to be of no practical use to the Indians and new and more favourable reserves have been recommended for different families scattered over a territory many miles distant from Ulkatcho. A glance at the map on page 284, Vol. I of the report of the Royal Commission, will give you an idea of how impossible it would be for the children to attend a day school at the old village of Ulkatcho if it were desirable to establish one there.

Dear Dr. Scott,

On July 28th I was near a camp of Indians from Ulkatcho, which was situated on Mud Bay in the Bella Coola valley, about 35 miles above its mouth. Head Chief Squinas of the Ulkatcho Indians, and Charlie West and Alexie, both of Ulkatcho, came to me and requested me to tell the head chief of all the Indians of Canada at Ottawa the following, which they said is what Captain Harry, Stillas, Ulkatcho Johnnie, and Ulkatcho Sill, who were all also of Ulkatcho, would wish to be said were they present. There is no school at Ulkatcho. There are more than 30 children there, some of them 15 years old, some 6, some 5, and some 20. There are also some children at Clasolas Lake. This would make about 50 altogether who would come to Ulkatcho if there was a school there, and more than that would come.

The land at Ulkatcho is barren and stoney, and soon the beaver will be no more. Every man wants one piece of land in the Bella Coola valley where he can make potatoes. We cannot
make potatoes up at Ulkatcho because they die because it is too dry, but we want to be allowed to continue to hunt at Ulkatcho. Each man wants about 40 acres or 60 acres where he can make potatoes and dry salmon and make a house. It is too cold for chickens in Ulkatcho, but in the Bella Coola valley they could be kept. We have tried to keep chickens and they were frozen at Ulkatcho.

Squinas, Charlie, Alexie, Captain Harry, Sill, Sundayman, Ulkatcho Johnnie, Leon, Old John, Stillas, Phelix, 11 men in all, each want land, 440 to 550 acres in all. We want one big land and divide up inside for each head of family. All understand how to irrigate.

We don't want to send children to Chilliwack school. If we send the children to Chilliwack, the boys and girls get too high toned and think just like white people and don't care for us, and we want to see our children. We want to make potatoes, pigs, chickens, hay, apple trees, cattle and horses.

We want the head chief of all the Indians of Canada at Ottawa to write to us and send a copy of the letter to each of us three, telling us what he thinks of this matter.

We hear the fire has burned Charlie's mowing machine and his house and all his winter supplies, but we do not know yet. We want to work where we can catch a living. If we get a rich land and move to it we would not want a school at
Ulkatcho but at the new place. We don't want to have to stay in the potato land. We want to put horses where there is horse feed and hay at Ulkatcho. There is no good land for cattle at Ulkatcho. If we get good land we do not all want so many horses, just enough to work the land.

We are not the same as the Bellacoola Indians. The Bellacoola Indians have brush all around their houses. If we had such land we would clean it all and fence it.

If it goes on as it is, it will be the same as if you kill us—no land, no moose, no beaver, we die. We want a place between Canoe Crossing and Stewie, because some of that land is good and not yet taken up by white men. We want enough so that when our children are married they can have land too.

A copy of this letter has been sent to each of the three Indians above mentioned in accordance with my promise to them. They told me that sometimes they do not get their letters, but that if the letter was sent to all three certainly one of them would receive it. They also wish you to send your reply to each one of the three or if you write to me for me to send copies of your letter to each of them. They told me there was practically no white man in their part of the country around Ulkatcho who would write a letter for them to which they could be sure of getting a reply.
I am also sending a copy of the letter to Mr. Fougner for his information. You and he will appreciate that it is difficult for me to understand exactly what the Indians want and for them to make themselves exactly understood.

I have very kind and sympathetic feelings for these Indians who confide in me and expect my sympathy and help. I understand that they tell me pathetic things which they do not tell to white men as a rule. You will know better than I what can be done.

Yours very respectfully,

Harlan Smith

Dear Mr. Scott,

While I was at Bella Coola last summer, Mr. Adolphe Christiansen, store-keeper, and one of the two leading men of Bella Coola, told me that the Indians of Ulcatcho were in need of schooling, and that sometimes when he was there buying furs and the weather was bad he held a little school for their benefit. He told me that something should be done about getting schooling for these Indians.

I do not know exactly where these Ulcatcho Indians live, or how many are close enough together to be served by one school. There were a number of Indians generally known as Stick Indians, most of whom I believe were Carriers, who came to Bella Coola and stayed perhaps a month and a half. Some of them worked at haying while they were there for the white people, but I think most of them were concerned chiefly with getting their winter supplies, and incidentally perhaps making their visit long in order to escape the flies which are said to be very bad in their country in the middle of the summer.
By flies they mean to include mosquitoes.

Charlie West, a very decent Indian who worked for me by the hour, and is known perhaps better under the names "Handsome Charlie" and "Pretty Charlie", told me several times that they wanted a school for their children. He asked me not to talk Chinook Jargon to him, as he did not understand much of it, and as he wanted to learn English. He told me several times he wanted me to teach him English. He said he came from Ulcatcho, but exactly where he meant by that I do not know, as I think the Indians who came to Bella Coola were from scattered places in the vicinity of Anahim Peak. It was pitiful to me to see how keenly he wanted to have schooling for his family, and I was told he was a very steady worker. He certainly was a good worker for me, and he asked me to employ him if I ever came there again.

Capoose, who is supposed to be an Ulcatcho Indian, and certainly is a man of considerable wealth, also told me that his people needed schooling. He talked of this constantly, asking my advice as to how he could get appointed as a school teacher. He said he understood the Indians and was smart, and could teach them in a way so that they would learn in a very short time. He is a smart man, but I am not sure but what he may be a bit tricky. He is one of the most
peculiarly smart Indians I ever met in a sly sort of way so much so that I suspect that he may not be pure blood.

Mr. Huber, who is the only man living at Firvale—
I do not know that there is a postmaster there now and believe they get their mail by rural delivery from Bella Coola, and mail addressed to him at Firvale or Burnt Bridge would reach him—asked me what could be done about schooling for the Indians of the Interior who came to Bella Coola. He referred to these Ulcatcho Indians as I understood him. He wanted me to do whatever I could at Ottawa for them. He called to me especially for this purpose. He said it was a shame that these Indians who wanted education had no opportunity to get it.

You could get more exact information regarding the situation from these gentlemen or from Mr. Faugner, the Indian Agent at Bella Coola. I did not talk with Mr. Faugner about the matter. He would certainly give you his honest opinion and truthful information, although my impression is that he thinks the Indians are more or less hopeless.

From what I saw of these Indians, I think they are rather better off than any other Indians I have seen in regard to economic conditions. They are apparently workers. I understand their country is one where ranching, cattle and horse raising will be rapidly taken up. I understand some of
these Indians have a large number of horses and considerable money. I trust a way may be found to relieve them in this matter of education for their children. I feel they do not know how to make their cry heard as far as Ottawa, and that they feel it is not much use asking the white man for things, although they would be quick enough to ask Christiansen and such other white men as they meet and know to be their friends.

If nothing better could be done, a school during the time that they visit Bella Coola at that place would at least give them something. I suppose Mr. W.H.Gibson at Bella Coola could give you full information as to what could be done for them there and about them, although I do not know that he has ever been up in their country, which is between one and two hundred miles away. I hope to continue work the coming summer at Bella Coola, and to again meet these Indians, and I should be very glad to carry them some good message in regard to this matter.

Yours very sincerely,

Sir,

Mr. Marlan I. Smith of Ottawa has sent me a copy of a letter dated November 13, 1928, addressed to Dr. Duncan Campbell Scott, Deputy Sup't General, Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa.

I will reply to this at once, as I shall be busier later on, and away from the office, on a lengthy trip up the coast.

The matter of a school at Ulkatcho has previously been thoroughly weighed by our Department; and the decision arrived at is that a day school at Ulkatcho would not be a success, as the Indians are at home in the village for only brief periods at a time. There are not enough children for a boarding-school, and arrangements have been made that Ulkatcho children be admitted to the Catholic boarding school at Fort Fraser. These Indians are all Catholic.

It is true that the old Indian reserve at Ulkatcho is practically all waste land. It is rocky highland plateau, mostly covered with jack pine, and at such an altitude that it is subject to summer frosts. This was pointed out to the Royal Commission for B.C. Indian lands, and this Commission cut away the greatest portion of the old reserve, and recommended several pieces of meadow land in its stead. We did not get what we wanted; but it was the best that could be done, under the circumstances, as the Government did not wish to buy land from private individuals or companies; only Government land was available.

When these Indians now, through Mr. Smith ask for land, where they can grow potatoes, in the upper part of the Bella Coola valley, this may seem a fair and reasonable proposition. Whether it would work out well is problematical and unknown. We can to some extent see into the unknown, by looking at the nearest related known. Some years ago Frank Sill, and Capoose, two of the wealthiest, and most enterprising of the Ulkatcho Indians bought land from white settlers in this part of the valley. The land had houses, and clearings; the houses are not kept in repairs, and the land that once was cleared is growing up with brush. The land is used for pasture by the Indians on their travels between Ulkatcho and Bella Coola. We believe Capoose's wife has raised a few acres of potatoes on their land; these they carried up to Ulkatcho or neighboring country on horseback; here are no wagon roads. They camp at these places, and catch salmon for their winter supply.

Dr. D.C. Scott, Deputy Sup't General,
Indian Affairs, Ottawa.
Some of these Indians are no doubt poor, and have received relief from our Department; one is totally blind, and our Department is supporting him. On the other hand some are quite wealthy. To support this, I can relate that in the summer of 1921, Frank Sill and his wife came into this office. Sill said he had some money that he wanted me to look after for him. I promised that, and his wife pulled out from her bosom the sum of $3000.00, and handed to me. Of this I deposited $1000.00 in the Bank of Montreal, and bought Saving Certificates for $2000.00. These amounts are yet untouched, and the bank pass book, and the certificates are kept in this office.

As to the concluding paragraph of the letter I may say that Mr. Smith is very much interested in the Indians, and kindly disposed to them. This feeling, no doubt is reciprocated by the Indians. But Mr. Smith is an archaeologist, and therefore it is not unreasonable to believe that he knows more of the dead Indians than of the living ones. Our Department has to deal with the living ones, and to do that in the best manner is not altogether an easy task.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent,
Bella Coola Agency.

Dear Sir,

Re: School for Ulkatcho Indians.

Since writing my letter of March 22nd, I have had several meetings with the above mentioned Indians. They are very desirous of having a school, and after listening to their various arguments, I consider that Ulkatcho would be a more practical place for the school than at Anaham Lake, as previously suggested. Ulkatcho is the home reserve of the majority of the Indians of this Band. They are willing to cut the logs and erect a building 16 by 24 feet, if the Department can supply the lumber for floors, ceiling, shingles etc. They further agree to leave the children with their mothers at Ulkatcho for five months in the winter.

There are twenty-five children of school age at Ulkatcho, none of whom have been to any Residential School. There are also a number below school age. The Priest informs me that the teacher, who must be a man, could board with the merchant there, Mr. John Ward. In view of the high cost of living in that district, I would recommend that the teacher's salary be not less than $100 per month.

There are also fourteen children of school age at Anaham Lake who could not be accommodated in a school placed at Ulkatcho. I believe that later it might be possible to employ the same teacher for five months at Ulkatcho and five months at Anaham which is forty miles from Ulkatcho, if a suitable building could be secured there.

I am writing Mr. Indian Agent Taylor asking if it would be possible to purchase the necessary lumber and material at Willows Lake, and the cost. I will advise the Department later as to this.

The Indians are willing to begin work on the log building this fall, after having. I recommend that the Department sanction this and also that they be allowed $100 worth of groceries, as their food supplies are very poor. If this can be done, I will make provision in my estimates for the necessary lumber etc., and teacher's salary, so that the school can be completed in the spring of 1939 and be ready to open in November, 1938.

I shall be going in to Ulkatcho early in September, and I should like to be able to inform the Indians if the Department will give them food supplies so that they can begin to work this fall.

Your obedient servant,

J. Gillett,
Indian Agent.

REPORT ON BELLA COOLA INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF JUNE, 1944.

Schools;

The day schools operating in the agency are now closed for the summer vacation. Detailed reports on the progress and teaching standards have been submitted to Commissioner MacKay. From reports received to date, there are no teachers in sight for either of the two rooms at Kitamaat or for the seasonal school at Ulkatcho. In connection with the latter, this building and the teachers quarters should be insulated before a new teacher is appointed. The buildings are not well enough constructed to withstand the 30 to 40 below zero weather prevalent at Ulkatcho in winter time.

Herewith quarterly report of the Agent, Bella Coola Indian Agency, also administering the Skeena River Agency, for the period ending June 30th, 1946.

EDUCATION: Bella Coola Agency, schools at Bella Coola, and Bella Bella were inspected during the quarter. Provision has been made to open two rooms at Bella Coola this fall, and negotiations to open a third room at Bella Bella are proceeding. The school at Upper Deen River is almost ready to open, that at Ulkatcho will remain closed. For Kitimat, we have the application of Gordon Robinson to teach this fall. He has Normal School this past winter and did very well indeed. His work at Kitimat will be watched with very real interest.

P. Earl Anfield,
Indian Agent.
These schools were also visited by Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, during October and in addition the new school buildings at Anaham Lake. I might say that I received a letter from Chief Louis Squinas of Ulkatcho Band who advises me that these Indians are very much enthused about getting school started and I am very disappointed that it has been found impossible so far to get a teacher for them.

The school opened on January 18th 1943. The lateness of opening was due to the difficulties of travel and transport. There were no holidays during the period the school was open.

MEMORANDUM FOR FILE:

Salary cheque for Mr. C. F. MacKinnon, teacher of the Ulkatcho Seasonal School, should be sent in care of the Indian Agent at Bella Coola, B.C.
The Secretary
Indian Affairs Branch
Department of Mines & Resources
OTTAWA.

Dear Sir,

re Colin F. MacKinnon, teacher at Seasonal Indian Day School at Ulkatcho, B.C.

I have just received a letter from the above-named Colin F. MacKinnon who is my son, and after talking with Capt. Barry, the inspector here, am writing regarding my son's monthly cheque.

It will be quite useless to send the cheques anywhere but to my address, 4619 - W. 7th Ave., Vancouver, B.C.; the reason being that where my son is teaching is sixty miles over mountain trail from the nearest post office of Anahim Lake. Even at Anahim Lake there is no Bank or other institution where he could negotiate his cheques. So if you send them here I can deposit them to credit of his own account with a Bank here. Meantime I have to keep him supplied with food, etc., which is practically unobtainable at Anahim Lake and absolutely unobtainable at his station, Ulkatcho.

As the authorities here are not at all conversant with this place, Ulkatcho, I imagine you are without information concerning it and may be glad to have something on file. It is not shown on any map, I think; but if you will look at the map you will find Anahim Lake shown about 75 miles inland (East) from Bella Coola which is on the coast and is a steamer port of call for Union Steamship Co., steamers running between Vancouver and Prince Rupert. Not far from Anahim Lake you will notice Kleena Kleene. Now the way to get into Ulkatcho (and the way mail goes in) is from Williams Lake via stage westward to Kleena Kleene, thence by another stage from Kleena Kleene to Anahim Lake where the postal service ends. From there it must depend upon a trapper or other person who may be passing through. Mail cannot reach the abovenamed places via Bella Coola; and Ulkatcho is inaccessible from Bella Coola.

The teacher informs me that, at date of his letter Nov. 24th, he was waiting for lumber, etc., for making desks and other equipment to come from Anahim Lake. He was using tarpaper for blackboards, and remarked it was quite serviceable. He remarked (and I think one can appreciate the truth of it) that it is "no softie's job." He says the children are quite bright and already he has accomplished almost what the department lays down for the half year's work. Some of the prices of necessaries he mentions as follows: potatoes 10¢ per lb.; condensed milk 25¢ per can; coal oil $1.50 per gallon.

However, as the Department is aware, it involves a long and difficult trip with pack-horses for the Agent to visit this point and, consequently it is not easy for him to give these matters the close supervision that is possible with more accessible areas in his Agency.

Dear Sir:

Your file 15/2/9641
Re Ulkatcho Seasonal School.

Your letter of the 16th instant with Mr. MacKinnon's letter to the Commissioner of January 3 enclosed is acknowledged.

The completion of the teacher's residence at Ulkatcho has given me some concern and it was my intention to ask for the necessary authorization to complete the building as soon as possible since the Priest's house was not a suitable building and in poor condition.

Accordingly I made arrangements with the Indians to haul in this lumber but told them they would have to wait until they heard further from the Department, with the exception of one team to convey lumber for seats and desks which had already been delivered at Anaham Lake by Stanley Dowling.

After my return from Ulkatcho I phoned Englebretson to get his quotation on the lumber but was informed that they had no lumber on hand and would not be able to supply any until March. In these circumstances there did not seem much to be done about it.

However, while I was at Vancouver three Indians with sleighs came down to Anaham Lake and succeeded in getting 1,000 feet of lumber from Stanley Dowling, also a stove with a drum oven which is also necessary for the teacher.
Dowling phoned Mr. Levelton about supplying the Indians with food and some clothes which they required, in lieu of wages for hauling in these supplies. Mr. Levelton informed me that he did not give Dowling any such permission. Taking into consideration that these supplies to complete the teacher's residence were urgently required and also the fact that the Indians would have had over 120 miles round trip for nothing I am of the opinion that Dowling used good judgement.

The following expenses have been incurred:

**From Stanley Dowling**
- 1,000 feet of lumber F.O.B. Anaham Lake $30.00
- 8 bundles shingles 10.00
- 1 camp stove 13.00
- 1 drum oven for stove 5.00
- 10 stove pipes 2.50

**From Sulin**
- 500 feet lumber 9.00

**Freighting**
- To Dowling.
  - For mdse. supplied James Jack 20.00
  - " " " Charlie West 20.00
  - " " " Frank Sill 20.00

**Balonic Squinas**
- To hauling 500 feet of lumber from Tougstan 20.00

**A. C. Christensen**
- Mdse. supplied James Jack for constructing seats and desks. 22.40

$171.90

It is very much regretted that this expenditure has incurred in this irregular manner. That it is necessary cannot be denied for if a school is going to be operated there the teacher must have a place to stay and very few teachers would have undertaken the position of teacher at Ulkatcho under the conditions which prevailed when school was opened. It was realized by the Agent that there was some risk recommending these commitments by the Department.
to the expense of a school at this point especially since this Band have been considered for the last twenty years to be too nomadic for a school to be feasible and it might reasonably have been assumed that the only way out was for these children to attend a Residential School. That these children had never apparently had the opportunity of attending a Residential School is another matter for conjecture, but it is quite possible that the parents may have objected to the children leaving home. The present Seasonal School will accomplish much more for parents and children and the total cost has not yet reached $850.00 spread over three years. Of this amount the Indians have received $424.40 in food and clothing for work and freighting. Considering that most of the material was transported from Vancouver by truck and sleigh over almost impossible roads and trails and that this includes school furnishings, the Department has received very good value for the money expended.

Your obedient servant,

Wm. Christie,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I must advise that I found it necessary to authorize the purchase of certain lumber and furnishings for the Ulkatcho Indian Day School, Bella Coola Indian Agency.

The total amount involved is $79.90 and action was taken without the usual reference to the Department because, the matter was urgent, and there was an opportunity to get the lumber and furnishings delivered at Anahim Lake by truck.

Dear Sir,

Re: Atkinson School Grant

Referring to our recent conversation & trust you will again lay this matter before your Department.

We feel that, as it at present stands we have some reason to complain.

We began work in Atkinson in December 1895 when no one else was there, either Protestant or Roman Catholic.

Many years ago the latter had a school here for a season or two but to all intents and purposes had permanently abandoned the tribe a large and important one. Had the Roman Catholics been engaged in that field we should not have gone there. But for several years before they had not nor have they since done anything to give them any claim upon this field.

Nor does it make it easier to understand to say that the grant was transferred from Atkinson to Clayoquot.

The Secretary:-

Memo. re overture submitted to the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in Canada and transmitted to the Department through the Synod of British Columbia, by the Presbytery of Victoria, B.C., in regard to grants to Indian Mission schools on the West Coast of Vancouver Island.

I. The Statement of the Presbyterian Church above referred to deals chiefly with educational matters in connection with the Ahousaht Band which, according to the last census, contains 276 members, made up as follows: - 80 Presbyterians, 80 Roman Catholics and 116 pagans. The Presbyterians claim that they opened a school at Ahousaht in Dec. 1895, but the first return received by the Department from their school was for March quarter 1896, and since then quarterly returns have been regularly received, the last return showing an enrollment of 47 with an average attendance of 24.

Previous to the opening of a Presbyterian school at Ahousaht, the Roman Catholics had been carrying on a school at that place, but no returns have been received from that school since 1891, when the school was apparently closed. Mr Vowell, in a letter of the 22nd Nov. 1895, submitting an application from Rev. Mr Swartout of Ucluelet for permission to open a day school at Maktosis (Ahousaht), states that the Roman Catholics had a school for the
Indians of that Band some years ago, and that the name of this school has been entered in the Estimates for day schools from year to year, although returns had ceased to be received. He also states that the Roman Catholic missioners have a church and residence for the priest there, one room of which was formerly used as a school room and that it would be well to delay the introduction of a different sect of religion amongst these Indians until a vote of the whole tribe was taken on the question. Acting on Mr Vowell's recommendation, he was advised that the Department regretted being unable to comply with Mr Swartout's request, as no funds were available for the establishment of a Protestant school on that Reserve.

Although the Department had not sanctioned the opening of a Presbyterian school at Ahousaht, nor promised any aid, quarterly returns were forwarded by the Agent, but no requisition was made for a grant as none had been allowed. Payment, however, was made for the first three quarter's salary, amounting to $225, such payment having been made in error and Mr Vowell was so informed. The grant included in the estimates was for a Roman Catholic and not a Presbyterian school at that place.

2nd. The statement of the Church authorities as to the opening and payment of the Roman Catholic school at Clayoquot is correct in so far as it refers to the years 1896-7 and 1897-8, but it should be borne in mind that the Roman Catholic church authorities were given the option of keeping either one of the two schools open, and chose Clayoquot. Since 1898-9 Ahousaht has been dropped from the estimates.
3rd. The priority of occupation claim of the Roman Catholic church is held by the Presbyterian authorities to be untenable for the reasons set forth in their memorandum, although acknowledged by the Department, for the reason set forth by Mr Vowell in his letter above referred to, and it is a question I do not feel competent to express an opinion upon.

4th. An application was received last spring from the Presbyterian church for a grant to the day school conducted by that denomination at Ahousaht which was submitted to the Deputy Minister, who directed that the Rev. Mr Swartout be informed that it was too late to arrange anything then. The Deputy also added that no promise was to be made in the matter. I understand that nothing has been provided for this school in the estimates for next year; but as the Presbyterians have successfully carried on the work so many years, it would seem that they are entitled to consideration, but if a grant were made them, I do not think that they are entitled to payment from the time the school was opened, as they claim in the concluding paragraph of their memorandum.

QUARTERLY REPORT ENDING SEPTEMBER 30th, 1945, ON WEST COAST AGENCY

INSPECTION OF SCHOOLS:

Ahousat Day School on day of inspection had an attendance of only three pupils; two of whom could not read. This was partly due to families being away at the Canneries. On the whole this school was very disappointing, and I feel that the teacher is wasting her time.

Day schools is emphasized. The school at Ucluelet should be re-opened if a teacher can be found. Season day schools also should be conducted at Noatka, Kildonan, and Ceepeecree, as the parents cannot leave their children behind when employed at the Canneries; and the residential schools cannot accommodate them. REGISTERED
Dear Doctor Dorey:

Ahousaht Indian Day School.

I have for answer your letter of May 7th with regard to the above Indian Day School.

As I advised you in our telephone conversation of this morning our District Inspector of Indian Schools for British Columbia has previously recommended that we consider the erection of a new Day School at this point. Due to previous commitments, it is not anticipated that this building will be erected this summer. However, it is high on Inspector Davey's list of required schools for British Columbia and it is expected that it will be included in our 1949-50 Estimates.

In view of the above recommendation, the Department would like to be advised further with regard to the views of those members of the Women's Missionary Society who were of the opinion that a Residential School should be built at Ahousaht.
